description: This cafe holds a special place in my heart because of what it represented to me not too long ago: a place to escape the hellish marriage I found myself in a little over a decade back. I used to go there and get chocolate skinny cow shakes and read a book, or sometimes just get a coffee and people watch on Polk. Sadly, the skinny cow shakes are long gone and the menu has become more vegetarian and environmentally friendly but that's San Francisco for you. Still, the interior is a comfortable space and it IS nice that tasty sandwiches can be purchased now.
author: Frank L.

description:
The food here is very good. The staff is friendly. The location is great. The space itself is excellent, with plenty of seating and electrical outlets. 

However, I could not get the wifi to work. I struggled with it for an hour, and the staff was unable to help me. My laptop generally has no problems connecting anywhere else, and I was able to connect through my phone's data connection, although that is a less than optimal solution. Having come here specifically to get some work done, the non-functional wifi was a dealbreaker. 

It appears that I was the only one having problems with the wifi, so it is possible that whatever the issue is it was unique to me. At other cafes in the past when I had problems the barista offered to reset the router, which usually fixed things.
author: John C.

description:
Watch your belongings closely here! Tuesday July 10 at 4 PM my wallet was stolen from my backpack that was hung on the back of my chair. I was sitting at the bar seating near the front counter. The guy sitting behind me quickly unzipped and reached in the backpack. I realized what had happened when I got up to leave and noticed my backpack was wide open and my wallet was gone.

Yes, I realize I should have been more aware (I was focused on my computer). The management and employees there also need to be more aware and kick out the homeless/junkies/pick-pockets that just wander in and loiter around the cafe unchecked and free to steal from the customers. They really need to hire a security guard.

Description of the thief is: African American Male, 45 to 55 Years Old, 6ft + Tall, Baseball Cap, Oversized Sport Coat and Khaki Baggy Pants.

The cafe manager said the security video camera captured the moment of the theft, but he couldn't see the guy's face clearly. I remember him sitting behind me and I thought he looked homeless, but also thought he was harmless. Man was I wrong. He's likely a pro street-thief.

Sit here at your own risk. On second thought, just go somewhere else. This cafe is definitely Not Safe and Sketchy AF!
author: Dan F.

description: This place use to be great. Im giving it this review because one of the workers had the nerve to tell me that seating outdoors is for customers only. I was a customer there,meanwhile some guy that is clearly not a customer just sat down to use the WiFi, the worker ignores him. I ask the worker why stop at me? I told him that was fuc%$d up and he has the nerve to get offended. So for that reason I give it a crappy review!
author: Shaun Y.

description: Was denied service at 9:30pm, listed closing time is 11pm. This was a frequent stop-off during work for me but not anytime soon.
author: Sean E.

description: We were looking for wifi and found this place. The sandwich and hot chocolate are surprisingly good. Not many people here in the evening and the space is perfect for working or studying.
author: Sophie C.

description: There's some vibe on this place that is not doing it for me. This place is part of my neighborhood they try so many different thing to attract people but is usually empty with the exemption on weekends when is packed of homeless. The staff is not doing it for me at all yes they're friendly but something about them is just not right. Today was the 3rd time on 3 years that I stopped here I gave it a last chance and again, something it's just not worth it about Quetzal... let me not forget that Quetzal it's Mexican mystical animal and this place has nothing Mexican at all... don't waste your time here.
author: Lola P.

description: This place is awesome! My friend and I needed a chill coffee shop with free WiFi for an afternoon of cranking work out on our laptops. We had great natural sunlight, a huge table, and friendly staff taking care of us. We got some chai lattes then transitioned to some wine as work began to get the best of us. Super chill place to work/drink/eat alone or with friends, SF needs more like it!!
author: johnna m.

description: If you ever find yourself taking a loved one to the Eye Surgery Center on Post Street and are need of drink and snack, Quetzal Cafe is down the block on Polk St. It's safe 10:00am. People here are young and old working on their computers and talking on their phone as well as visiting! The toasted sesame bagel with lox and cream cheese was delicious and soy chai was enjoyable!
author: Stephanie T.

description: Came here for the first time for lunch. Ordered a burrito for here. Sat and waited for my food. My lunch hr was up so I went up to ask for my food to go instead and they were confused. Not a good first impression here.
author: Zenas S.

description: There a no computers here. False advertising. They said for 2 years there have been no computers. Disappointed they still advertise as a place where you could come to use the Internet and display pictures of computers on this yelp page.
author: Joseph W.

description: Weak coffee, weak service, overpriced food. There are better businesses to support in the neighborhood. Even the Peet's up the street is a better place
author: Peter J.

description:
If variety is the spice of life, Quetzal Internet Cafe is a spicy place.  Breakfast, bagels, lattes, smoothies, crepes, and so on.  Beer, wine and mimosas for the afternoon.  Happy hour prices!
I had a latte and a toasted bagel with cream cheese that were reasonably priced, of solid quality and served quickly.

Now the decor is not spicy.  If you are coming to get work done and/or hook up to the net, this is your man.  If you are looking for art on the walls, no.  The place has the feel of a cafe bogged onto the side of the student union building at a state college.  Lots of exposed cinder block, multi-level seating with long tables to fit a crowd or to spread out. They should paint the walls with a Mayan motif to match the name.  This average Joe will be back as it serves quickly with solid food and drink.
author: Derald C.

description:
Have tried so far only a Nutella crepe but it was well and quickly made as well as quiet delish!!! Asked for extra Nutella (you know that one time you treat your self for breakfast !) and they have accommodated the request for no addition charge. Pretty awesome!
The two ladies taking orders/cashier were kind, smiley and attentive. The guy whom made my crepe did a good , fast job too.
Overall very satisfied with the experience!
I paid 6.19 $ including taxes and tips. Nutella crepe it self is only 4.95 , differently from their neighbors usury Oh la la crepe whatever, charging almost 10 dollars for a freaking crepe! By the way are they out of their mind or whatttt???! Will just never step in there. Its really not about the $$$, I am not cheap over good food but it is a matter of principal. Cause com'on a crepe almost 10$?!? Well they can keep it. 
But back to the Quetzal cafe'!
 Sensation My 4.95$ with extra Nutella crepe was accompanied but free fresh fruit. Yep yep! How awesome is that?!
Will be looking forward to come back for another items. I spot veggie bagels for also 4.95 ( I think) which will come with cream cheese , fresh tomatoes,cucumber and avocado !! Yum yum, tummy fun fun
Oh and they serve organic, fair trade coffee too!!!
Posting along my crepe pic, some menu pics as well!
If you haven't yet Try this place , well give it a shot. It is well deserved.
author: Hosna A.

description: We found this place just walking by and decided to stop and I'm glad we did . They have very good,  my husband and I got sandwiches and they were really good.  They have free WiFi and serve alcohol.  We liked it so much we ate there twice.  I would definitely recommend it  !
author: Tanisha H.

description: Ordered UberEats and it was awful!!! All of my food  and drinks had been tampered with. Matcha latte came half empty, smoothies looked like someone took some gulps out of it, and at that point, I didn't trust any of the food to even touch it. Please next time properly seal the food and drinks especially with shady UberEats drivers who always arrive high and do not take proper care of the food and drinks during delivery.
author: Holly M.

description:
This place is really nice on the inside. It's clean, spacious and has that modern hostel feel. 
The woman at the register was really friendly which is always a plus. 

They offer wifi and have places to charge your computer, and they also offer Ethernet cables which I thought was really cool. 

I ordered a veggie melt from them which was pretty good, but also really hard to mess up. 

I also ordered an iced "matcha" latte. I put it in quotes because it was everything you don't want your matcha latte to be. 

She used either half and half or heavy cream. Which is fine, but dear god I was hoping there'd be matcha in it. The faint matcha flavor was so nonexistent I was shocked it even had matcha in it. 
It literally felt like I was drinking iced half and half. Never again. 

Aside from the matcha latte this place is a good place to work and have a light lunch.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Was looking for a spot to grab a light lunch and some coffee with a friend. Found this spot and it was pretty good. 
I got the chicken caesar salad sandwich and my friend got the turkey club. (Each were about $8-9)
Chicken sandwich was good-although they put too much chicken. Was hard to even bite the sandwich as it was so tall and big. Once you take some of the chicken out, it's not a bad sandwich. The chicken they use is some precut/pre cooked chicken. Probably the frozen stuff. Little bland. Nothing gourmet about it. However, they use great focaccia bread! Super yummy bread and a nice little caesar dressing on it to make it flavorful. 

Can't comment on the turkey club that my friend got since I didn't try it. She liked it and it looked like an average turkey sandwich you would order. 

The place is nice and big and we didn't have any trouble finding seats on a rainy Sunday afternoon. They have a ton of options for food and lots of coffee and tea choices too!

Nice spot to stop in at, grab a snack, drink and work if you need-seems like everyone was on a laptop.
author: Milena R.

description: They take forever to get you your food. Simple items take forever. So if you go in to get something easy prepare for a long wait.
author: Adam D.

description:
Quetzal's kind of a weird spot, with some interesting clientele... but holy balls do they have fast wifi. Plus their coffee's decent and they're open late.

I wouldn't go out of my way to cowork here, but if you're in the neighborhood it's a good place to get things done.
author: Nick S.

description: We went here for dinner. Ordered the rice crispy treat and brownie. The presentation was great. The wrapping was supreme. Buttt the rice crispy treat had a low m&m count. The brownie was less then moist. I decided to rate this place because they do offer internet.
author: Nelly D.

description:
I ordered a breakfast sandwich and large coffee.  Nice staff and quick service.  I didn't use WiFi but I saw lots of people surfing the internet.

Lots of seating and the area is safe even though it's near Tenderloin.
author: Wing W.

description:
Went here today to set up my new tablet and have a craft beer. Never did get to use the internet. They have this weird procedure where you need to text the word DESK to a number, wait for a code (which never worked), download an app called "Vinmo" first and "chip in" $3 for each hour you're on. Every coffee shop I've ever been in just get the password and you're good to go.
On the plus side the food looked and smelled good, lots of room, bright and airy with outdoor seating if you prefer. Glass of Sierra Nevada pale ale was $7.07. Little steep I think.
author: Tony F.

description:
I was in San Francisco for the AVP tournament by the Golden Gate Bridge, and this place was an absolute find! The coffee is great, the crepes are incredible, and their breakfast sandwiches and burritos are everything you'd want on a weekend. 
Also: They have an excellent beer selection. 
Pricing is great, food is great, and more importantly, the coffee and the beer are great. 
The interior, too, is clean, the staff nice, and the vibe wonderful.
Five stars.
Feel free to see more of my writing at papercourts.com.
author: Travis M.

description: Just got in to use the restroom. Bad to buy a bottle of water for that. The restrooms are smelling, filthy and dirty.
author: Yarin D.

description:
Updated review. 

They are so much better. Quick, precise and helpful. They seem to always be smiling and happy to help. I have never complained about the quality of food, it is all good, but the service was bad. I now have been in enough times and have had great interactions that I would recommend this place to all. 

Good job guys, way to step it up.
author: Timothy A.

description: Waited 15 min to get two quesadillas.  Neither had cheese, but were very messy, cold and not tasty - as we discovered after leaving the restaurant.  Should never have tipped!  We threw away the food.
author: Brian P.

description:
I'm only going to address the cafe as I experience it and remember it.  It used to be classier.  In the past, customers had a chance at real dining.  A waiter came to your table to serve water, gave you a menu, and took your order.  Today, the service is cafeteria style.  You stand in line and place your order with a cashier (if he or she is paying you any attention; otherwise, you have to call the cashier to attention or wait).  A service boy brings you your order and quickly disappears.  Receiving your order does not take long.  

The seating arrangement in the cafe is lousy.  Sunshine and its heat really burn up the place, keeping it overly warm when it's not winter, and the shades and windows look like they once belonged to Ms. Haversham's home from Charles Dickens's "Great Expectations" -- old, worn, and in disrepair, and the cement floors and metallic walkways turn the place into a noisy echo chamber.  

Why does a customer have to hear the prolonged, loud stomping of feet when a man or woman exits the bathroom two tiers up and walks all the way down the metal walkway and out the door?  

In the back area of this large restaurant, laptop-using students or computer nerds who have no intention of making their stay brief occupy the most comfortable and shaded spots available.  The rest of the seating area in the back is ablaze in bright sunlight with excessive heat such that even if you manage to endure the waiting period seated here waiting for your order, you will have to listen to the incessant chatter and monologizing of at least one or two of San Francisco's priceless, mental hospital escapees who also have no intention of making their stay brief.  Listening to whatever others cloistered in the back chatter loudly on their cell phones is no better treat.

The men's bathroom looks like a smudgy highway restroom at any anonymous gas station.  It used to be only customers used these facilities -- if the cashier gave you a key.  Today anybody can walk in and out -- without even being a customer, and that's the reason for the dark and smudgy way it looks.

The middle area where seating is close to the food bar so you can see the service boy exiting the kitchen with your order is often crowded as well, but it is an area that welcomes the less talkative and noisy.  There are holes in the long dining tables where your Internet connection goes.  Without a computer, you feel like you're just dining in a place that's like a garage that makes certain technicians happy to be there when they're there, but makes no sense to anyone else.  The holes don't have covers.  I guess the owner stopped replacing the stolen ones.

Lastly, there's the music that comes over the intercom.  The restaurant goes out of its way to appeal to young people, youth who view themselves as hip, as cool.  I listened to so much music from the Sixties on my first visit there that the songs forced me to relive my entire late adolescence and early twenties -- from Cat Stevens to Mick Jagger over and over again.  The second time I dined at Quetzal the music was of the type called world music with some sort of jazz-fusion spin to it.  Again, because the restaurant is an echo chamber, even low volume music makes you feel you're inside a large stadium with speakers going full blast.  

It never used to be like this.  The music used to be quieter and always tasteful and instrumental if a little boring.  You could eat in peace and be in your own world, not the world the service personnel chooses randomly for you.

The best part of Quetzal, however, is the food.  A lot of five-star reviewers speak of Quetzal's food.  I agree.  I have ordered the Cobb Salad over and over again, either to go or "for here."  It is absolutely healthy and delicious and there is artistry in its design or presentation.   It makes me happy just to look at it.  Under 10 dollars, this salad is a real bargain.  (But once I order coffee and pay the tax and the tip, the meal comes to $15.  That's a bit pricey.)  And, I think, the price is definitely worth the value you get.  I've checked out all the other restaurants in the neighborhood offering large salads or the famous Cobb Salad, and nowhere are you going to find in lower or upper Polk or lower Nob Hill such abundance at so low a cost as you find at Quetzal.  That's why I keep going.  The salad is good for me, filling and delicious, and the price, considering the competition, is completely reasonable, aka a real bargain.

I also recommend take-out.
author: Charles S.

description: I wouldn't call this the best coffee or the nicest looking coffeeshop, but it has a good amount positives to make it a solid cafe. It has an extraordinary amount of workspace and the internet is blazing fast. Not to mention the variety of items in the menu puts it well above most minimalist cafes around the area which brings me to my next statement. As I mentioned before, I wouldn't call the "coffee" a masterpiece or anything nor do they have the best pastries, so don't come here if those things are important to you, come here if you have a big group, want ample space to relax, or need the connection speed for work/school. And while you're here, take advantage of the food menu as well.
author: Timothy B.

description: Best place in the city for a cafe au le. Service of food items is slow but the coffee is worth the wait. The staff is always attentive and courteous which more than makes up for the slow food service. This is a great spot to work away from the office if you need a break or change of scenery.
author: Lyndsay M.

description: This place is incredible. Great food, coffee, wifi, service and space. Stop here to eat especially for breakfast (all day) and organic coffee at fantastic prices! It's an internet café so take advantage of the strong, free wifi.
author: David D.

description:
Here's what I look for in TRUE internet cafes from #1 MOST IMPORTANT TO #6 LEAST IMPORTANT:
1. BEING ABLE TO download THE INTERNET at a high rate, continuously
2. LOTS OF OUTLETS
3. SPACIOUS-lots of room so you can work in a private space without bumping into others
4. COMFORTABLE-has lots of little private tables with maybe some couches, sofas.  One thing I hate is those large rectangular sharing tables with benches where everyone is very near each other, side to side with each other
5. LONG OPEN HOURS
5. REST ROOMS-more than 1 or 2 stalls-Quetzal has a separation of men/women's bathrooms with at least 3 stalls for the women's bathroom(including a large stall for the handicapped)
6. COFFEE/FOOD-lastly, decent to good food at not too high prices--they serve frittatas, english muffin breakfasts, all kinds of healthy smoothies, delicious pastries & sandwiches

There are also tables outside the cafe if you'd rather enjoy the sun.
author: Frugal C.

description: I wish I read the reviews before I came here. I had to use the restroom but I had to buy something in order to do so. Silly me, I decided to get an egg breakfast and added bacon for $2. It was disgusting. My eggs were cold, like they were made earlier, my bacon was definitely microwaved, and the hash browns seemed like mashed school tater tots. Also, the bathroom seemed really sketchy and wasn't well lit. 2 stars only because the place looks nice, there's plenty of outlets, and strong wifi.
author: T. O.

description:
The food is mediocre, and the service is slow.  The whole place is poorly managed, disorganized and their employees speak English poorly.  That's probably why they got our orders--both of them--wrong.  How do you screw up an egg and cheese breakfast sandwich?  The place itself is a little weird.

UPDATE:  It has been about an hour since we ate here, and I have a horrible stomach ache.  Thanks, Quetzal, for whatever rubbish you try to pass along as food.  Try getting someone with actual cooking experience and buy better quality ingredients.
author: Amy R.

description:
Finding serenity from the madness of Polk is easy at Quetzal. The free WiFi is a huge plus for those of us who enjoy people watching and surfing the internet at the same time and the drinks aren't half bad. For those of you wondering, a quetzal is the national bird of Guatemala. No, I don't see a correlation either.

First timers might be initially confused when entering: does one sit down and establish a spot or order from the counter first? I can never decide. Judging by the other confused looks of patrons coming in, it's clear I'm not the only one. 

To ensure the staff I'm not here just to leech WiFi, I order something at the counter first and then pick my spot for the next hour or three. My spot will almost always be an area that has an outlet. Thankfully, there are plenty in every direction. If you choose to sit along the back wall (facing the front), then be prepared to share outlets.

When it comes to ordering something, I stick with drinks. Coffee / tea is available for caffeine chasers, but the smoothies keep me satisfied. A power shake with a little blackberry keeps me hydrated, even if it's not my favorite flavor in the world. In the 1st world, these are hardly problems.

Not feeling like any of the above? Shoot for their beer on tap. Nothing like sucking down a frosty one during the warmer months and surfing a little internet. Oh and they have a real happy hour deal ($3 on tap!), which goes until close. 

Then there is the food. I can't seem to stomach anything beyond breakfast. The smoked salmon scramble is among the only winners of the bunch, not be outdone from a slew of super subpar items that include: nachos, quesadillas, club sandwiches, pizzas, and salads. Save for a slice of quiche, pie, or something in their pastry lineup, but even those feel a tad overpriced.

Lastly, the internet connection I've experienced has been stellar so far. There have been some quips about low quality internet, but unless good luck has been on my side, I haven't had to deal with any slow speeds at all. If anything, it's the one thing that keeps me coming back.
author: Jando S.

description:
GO HERE!!!!!!!!

I go here every day on my way to work. I walk up from Civic Center every day and this spot is the perfect place on the way into the office! Esam is an extremely kind and generous owner/employee. For example, I ordered a chocolate croissant one day before realizing I didn't have the cash to cover it and after telling him this, he comped it for me!!
author: Aghlab Z.

description:
It's a fine place to work for a few hours - drinks are reasonably priced and decent. Wifi is strong, outlets are everywhere, and there's no lack of seating. Employees are friendly. Never come here for the food, though. Every dish I've ordered tastes like it was made yesterday in a microwave.

Coffee inexplicably tastes like chimneys.
author: Derek R.

description:
I've been here before the staff is mildly friendly sometimes there's a language barrier which has the cashier asking me to repeat myself multiple times, that can be annoying but i can handle all that. The prices are pretty pricey. Today I got 2 pastries for a little under $7. Wow, OK so they look trendy, place is always clean I get it all. What I don't get it how 1 of my pastries taste like sour mold and smells like mold. I discovered it by not smelling it first but simply putting it in my mouth, chewing and instantly tasting sour mold almost warm...disgusting. At my job ( a nearby restaurant) I literally spit it out into my hand in front of people....it was that bad....so I take it back seeing how I spent near 4 dollars for it and the girl tells me. "No it csnt be we just got those in this morning." So now I'm lying? I ask her to smell it I tell her to even taste it she continues to defend her pastry claiming "she'll show me the invoice from this morning ." I told her i didn't care if they received it aa I Walked in the store its rotten. She offers me another one....it's 5pm I've been at work all day I don't want  a pastry anymore I'm no longer hungry haven't been since chewing mold...I ask for a manager she goes in the back for 2 seconds and returns with "he's not here anymore." I took my pastry back and will be returning tonight to see if he's there. She kept saying "we just  got them in.." Like I'm gonna be like "Oh you did? Then me and  my coworkers who I made all taste a cheezit size piece of it were all making it up for $4


Update: yesterday in waking by cause I literally live on the same block as this place . And she stops me from inside and says "hey! I just wanted to say that I'm really sorry about what happened." The sound of her voice was sincere made me kinda feel bad for getting mad thst one day. She says "i can give you  a refund no problem." I smile and say "yes please that's all I wanted" She proclaims she offered me either a refund or a new pastry which doesn't make sense because why would I take my pastry back and why would I get so upset if she was offered what I came back to do? But for the sake of letting it go and moving on I said "well either way thank you very much I truly appreciate this." She says "I'm really sorry that happened" I say, "me too I was having the worst day so I'm sorry too" walked out feeling very pleased 

Oh ya and also went on to tell me how they no longer do business with that company that made me he pastry  which tells me I was right and they must of had
author: Paul S.

description: Came here on a whim bc I needed my afternoon coffee fix and something quick to consume. Ordered an iced coffee and a breakfast smoothie. McDonald's coffee would have tasted better. The coffee tasted so old. The breakfast smoothie was horrible I could only drink 1/8 of it. I ended up throwing it away. It was gritty and I could taste whatever protein powder they put in it. It was a waste of roughly $12, I pretty much threw both away because it was that bad.
author: Mary Ann B.

description:
After a special meal with an old friend I saw this place on the way back to the parking garage. The organic fresh roasted coffee is what drew me in. The inside is nice and spacious. Plenty of seating and tables for study or work. They carry some nice local cookies/pastries.

I tried the Americano. It was pricey (SF after all) and disappointing. Seemed weak. Ironically, didn't hold a candle for the Americano I had from Medleno's that very morning and it was nearly twice as much. 

I still give them 3 stars because it would be a great place to hang out.
author: Nora S.

description:
If you want to witness a microcosm of how basic communications skills have deteriorated irrevocably in modern society, come view the field of laptoppers at Quetzal. This is far less a coffeehouse for social mingling and more solitary confinement for those who want to be left alone staring at their screens. There were quite a few such people there, but I find it difficult to tag them as customers since I didn't see any evidence of food or even drink next to their self-imposed work stations. It just never appears to me that the staff there is clamping down on enforcing table turnover so that the rest of us could eat and chat.

Ah well, I have to concede "Internet" is in the name. That's probably the main reason I'm not tempted to have a full-fledged meal here. I end up here to have a $3.50 cup of coffee or tea after a meal with maybe a similarly premium-priced slice of pie like the one in the photo I provided (Blueberry Tart...good from what I recall). The staff doesn't appear to be pushing the food much despite what looks to be a robust menu of items in their online food menu. I didn't even know you could get breakfast here. I think the recent addition of the sidewalk parklet definitely helps open up the space, a good thing as I felt like I was in the library otherwise. Shhh...

COFFEE/TEA - 3 stars...quietly sipping, blisteringly hot
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...a large library with no books
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...unobtrusive, I guess
TOTAL - 3 stars...bring your laptop and leave me alone
author: Ed U.

description:
Tried this past twice, because wanted to give them a benefit of the doubt. But both times warranted a bad review. 

Both times purchased a pitcher of mimosas for $25. Already feel like it is a bad price, but even worse is that both times the pitcher was only 2/3 filled and not much champagne. Was practically drinking orange juice. 

Free wifi but it is consistently slow and have to ask to reset often. Bathrooms are terribly unkempt and without toilet paper. Service is poor. Not returning for a third time.
author: Will H.

description: Decent place for coffee or a beer and free internet:-) pretty good spot to get away fr hustle
author: Lesley F.

description:
I've been going to this place for years because the coffee is good. I also get some pastries, but lately they've been selling day old stale tasting pastries for full price. I've also been there for lunch 3 times and the sandwiches are dreary. The last sandwich I ordered was a turkey sandwich. The turkey meat was grayish-greenish and slimy. This was less than appetizing and made me sick even though I picked the meat out after the first bite. (See photo) Also a little over priced... almost $6 for a crepe.

The bathroom is often dirty, and tables sticky. There are always people smoking outside, smoke coming in the doorway.
author: tiger M.

description: Bad customer service. Just went in to try and order food and a drink as the cashier wanted to keep counting and recounting her tips and ignore me. I tried to order several times and she paid me no attention.
author: Derek B.

description:
The food is top notch, they get the details right that would be so easy for an average place to skip. It's like whoever is back there is genuinely thinking about how to make each dish as good as it can be for the person that's going to eat it. Portions are big, the cheese on my egg sandwich was fully melted and fully covered the egg and bacon below it, the slices of lox for my bagel and lox that I've also tried were thicker than I've ever seen, and the onion and tomato was placed under the lox so it was easy to cut and eat by hand without them falling off. The bagel was perfectly toasted, no burned spots but a nice dark, crisp toast all over.

It's also a great place to work, tons of seating, bar height and table height, good spots to people watch or just hide in a corner. Outlets all over, wireless is very good, and I've never been pestered about how long I stay. Outdoor seating in the parklet makes for a nice spot to take a lunch break with a cold beer. They put the tables and chairs out each morning and wipe them down so it's always clean despite on a somewhat busy and dirty part of Polk St.

Fair warning, this place can sometimes attract an interesting, probably homeless crowd, service can be somewhat inconsistent as it seems like the staff turns over quite a bit, and I've never been in when it was especially crowded so service could suffer during those times. The counters, tables, chairs are a bit rough around the edges, like they were built in someone's workshop as opposed to professionally constructed, but that's not a big deal, just makes it look a bit shabby.
author: Richard A.

description: Mocha is not good. They ask for a tip but then require you to go back and forth to get your coffee. Food is way overpriced. Small burrito for 9 bucks. Never coming back. Apparently the owner likes to message you on yelp, talking shit. Fuck this place.
author: Erick R.

description:
The coffee was ok 3 star out of 5. Customer service was HORRIBLE. the Asian B at the registrar was not helpful, friendly, or welcoming.

She gave a stinky face when my partner asked to use the restroom before ordering.... then asked me if my animal was a service dog, when i showed her her badge, the Asian B said, You don't have to show me, we work on the  honor system.   Well Asian B start trying to work on the Customer Service skills, be welcoming and friendly... NOT COLD and JUDGING 

We had our coffee and pastry spending just under 20.00  should not have left the 1$ tip for that crappy attitdue... ALSO you FLY/NAT infested Pastry rack looks good but work on the FLYS and NATS  

my apricot pastry was OK, as a chef, and pastry chef I did not expect to get diarrhea immediately after having their coffee and pastry, likely the cheep lard used in the pastry.

YUCK  WONT BE BACK   AFTER YEARS of LIVING IN SF coming back To Quetzal should have been nostalgic for a few reasons  HOWEVER NONE of that nostalgia lives at Quetzal it is an empty shell of a memory of good times and good coffee...
author: Pedro Proz P.

description: Great place to work out of for a few hours or so - coffee, huge space, many outlets, plentiful seating, and nice staff.
author: Shendi X.

description:
I was in here on a Wednesday morning when a disgruntled transient came in screaming and throwing items off the counter toward the barista. She handled the situation with calm assertiveness and poise as she, another young gentleman, and several regular customers helped escort all patrons outside to safety while the police arrived. When it was safe to come back inside, she had my order ready and a smile back on her face. 

I don't come here often, but I am certain I will make this place a regular habit from now on. The smoothies are amazing, the food is great, staff is professional and kind, and the wifi is FREEEEE! 5 Stars.
author: Teresa K.

description:
Watched the Brazil World Cup with one of the games versus the US and it was surely rowdy that time of day at this cafe located on Polk street!

Bars next door and cafés around the area were surely packed that day as well!

This cafe is a chill one after the game has been played on TV!  They serve up the usual cafe snacks and coffee while offering up complimentary Wi-Fi!

Adequate seating with plugs around!  Doable place!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Need to do some training on espresso drinks. Come here frequently when I get haircuts across the street and every time, regrettably, is disappointing...

Can't comment on the other menu items.
author: Noah F.

description:
I'm not sure this should be called a "cafe" it should be called Internet plus expensive mediocre food? 

The staff should smile and be a tad more helpful if I'm spending 8 dollars on a cup of tea and fruit.

The plus side is there are a ton of outlets and seats; so if you're anti social it's a good place to study or work for hours.
author: Amy A.

description: Excellent food and customer service. It is like a Statbucks but with more food and less expensive.
author: Luis P.

description:
Once every few weeks, a couple of my coworkers and I would come here on Tuesdays after work for their happy hours on beer. We love how the bench area outside is always vacant for us to chill and smoke cigarettes freely.

I've never tried anything else so I can't complain. This place isn't your usual happy hour bar type environment but I give it 5 stars cause it's perfect for a few people like us :)
author: Sharmaine M.

description: So waiting for my hair cut at people's decided to go get a coffee. I'm alone and I just want to grab a latte while I wait. Nice people very patient, but this is why I won't go here again. Coffee is pretty tasty, but I can't stand to pay for something for nothing. No one these days carries cash. I have a card as does the rest of the 2017 world uses for even minor things like $5 coffee. It's a business but when u nickel and dime it's not cute. Someone coming in and supporting your business and purchasing your goods or service is enough.... there are plenty of other places out there now. Why do you charge people a transaction fee for something less than $5? Plus when I upgraded to the $4.75 I'm ok with the additional .25 add on to make my transaction $5, but what I'm not ok with is the additional .50...... I'm confused why this place is charging .50 transaction fees. The credit card company's charging u those fees are the convenience of doing business. It doesn't matter how low my transaction is. Ok end of rant. If you go to this place bring cash is the advice given....
author: Troy B.

description: Extremely slow service. For a sandwich you can wait up to 20-25 min! This place has a lot of potential but right now it's really slimy and dirty and not taken care of. They have some weird huge handicap ramps in the middle of the place which take up almost half the space. I like their veggie melt panini but I do agree with other reviews- it is way overpriced.
author: Ana V.

description: Great place to study since the place is overflowing with sockets so you can charge all your devices. They have good food at a decent price, very nice staff and they play good music. also a lot of different types of chairs and table settings so you can choose depending on what you need to do. I definitely will try to go here as much as I can!
author: Camilla E.

description:
With the Tenderloin quickly becoming the trendyloin I would have to say that Quextal needs to step up their game.  

Large space for getting your work on but the coffee itself needs it's own pick-me-up.
author: Kevin J.

description:
I was a regular customer before the management change. The place was great,clean, good service, free trade coffee and a great coffee menu, that was all made well.  
The new owners changed the menu, for better or worse. The coffee is not as good and the place is a mess. The service also bad. 
based on my last visit and the poor service I received, I will not go bad. Lucky for me I can pick 5 other places to go to in the area.
author: Bob b.

description: We had a miscommunication with our order, and ended up getting the wrong item twice. It was not a big deal and I politely let the employees know of the mixup, and they were very defensive and adamant that I was the one who made a mistake. Overall, my experience here was defined by poor service, a long wait, and the wrong food.
author: Kartik S.

description:
Knowing you're staying in the Tenderloin you wouldn't expect much variety when it comes to nice coffee shops where you actually want to sit down and have a sip. Queztal is a beautiful exception here - I was pleasently surprised by both the athmosphere and the large selection of tea, different sorts of organic coffee, and sandwiches. 

Mostly I have to agree with my fellow Yelper Ed, although sometimes I'm the "bring your laptop and leave me alone" type of guy. To my excuse, getting some work done just feels better when you have friendly faces around rather than sitting in a small, depressive hotel room. 

coffee - 4 stars (fair trade, great tea selection, sandwiches and beverages available too)
ambiance - 4 stars (relatively spacious, Mac equipment (note: Internet cafe), lots of tables and seating)
service - 3 stars (nice and friendly)
author: Sebastian F.

description: I ordered the Waffles and I got an Eggo Waffle that was more than disappointing.  It also took like 20 minutes for them to bring it out, I guess they had to defrost it.  Then to make matters worse there was a few hopped up hobos that showed up and sat down next to my girlfriend and I and were selling/ buying stolen cellphone. The coffee was very meh too.  So go here if your in the market for a stolen cell phone from a crack head and you want an Eggo waffle and a bad coffee for 12 bucks.
author: Mike B.

description:
I wish I could rate this place 5 but no way to do it, although I got chance to meet with the owner one time had some talk, he is a great guy.!  But I never see him there, it s basicly the employee running the business,interacting with the customers.. I been coming here for at least 5 years now, seen many employees coming and going, but I think this new girl is worst of all, happy looking but unhappy..
  I think she said her name was Alice but sound was like saying Ellis, she looked mexican, she was short, looked like at least 250 lb , she had big hands, probably ready to knock down any man with one punch.! She also had a big mouth,
  Here how it did go on...,,
  On Friday around noon time I walk in and sign her, said hey could you buzz the bathroom door for me, 
She looked at me and said restroom is for the customers only, I said I m a customer, ( damn it I just need to use the bathroom first, wash my hands face before I get my tea and some food)  she took a little pause then I said I m a regular one, then she said I never seen you before.. so what is that mean I said, no bathroom?? She said no..  
  Hell a pissed off walk ed outside and keep looking for  another place to settle down for little while..
I walk towards to the water and just a couple blocks ahead fond my new spot, a new cafe that specialized on japonese food and drink called  sage cafe..
   But still would like to be able to go these place as well, when she is out of pic, and give this place, rating it deserves..
author: Wolfy E.

description: Snobbish service but good crepe and latte so I'm ok with that. Wifi is good too perfect for waiting and killing time
author: Noel O.

description: Great cafe with great internet. Stopped in here to get a bite while waiting for my haircut and the only complaint I have is how it smells outside. Definitely try it out if you need a place to hang out or study!
author: Bahram A.

description: This was the only place we could find that had bottomless mimosas during a weekday. For roughly $14, we got all the mimosas we wanted. The staff was polite except for the one comment, "it's too early to drink" from a guy who came to the front from the kitchen. My friend and I had 2 of their nutella crepes and they were delicious. Laid back atmosphere, nothing fancy. Not your typical brunch spot, but it worked!
author: Krystal P.

description:
This is my local coffee shop that I frequent at least once a week. I work in the area and its a good place to stop for a good cup of coffee, a smoothie or something to eat. I prefer to support local coffee shops than Starbucks and other chains. 

Quetzal is very big and has a lot to offer. They have an outdoor seating section with really nice new benches. Many table options inside as well, even a computer station area if you need to use a computer. No annoying loud music playing which is nice so you can concentrate on your own things. 

Their food is really good, a bit pricy but you get for what you are paying for. I have personally dealt with all of the employees there and they are all really great and kind. This is for people that have a laid back attitude if you are a Type A personality I suggest you stick to the run of the mill chain coffee places.
author: Kate D.

description:
Frustrating "internet" cafe -- no frieakin' internet! The three of us near where I am sitting are getting no internet access. I come because so close to home and a nice space to have a bite and do some work. But can't work; plenty other places to grab a snack *and* get internet. Will I be back. Dangit, probably yes. But I won't be happy.

Don't come if you plan to rely on internet access!!!
author: Brian L.

description: Wifi, open late, food, relaxed vibes... This is my ideal cafe. The barista is really nice as well.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
99.9999% sure our eggs were cooked in the microwave!? Gross. 

The internet wasn't working... when we asked about it, the workers behind the counter could have cared less (despite even in the name it's labeled an internet cafe!?)
author: Kali L.

description:
I came into Quetzal today and wasn't sure what I wanted to drink. After telling the girl at the counter that I wanted something hot, sweet and full of caffeine, she recommended an almond mocha and I LOVED it. Sometimes when you ask employees for recommendations they act annoyed or like you asked them to do complex algebra. This lady was really nice and came up with a great suggestion. I received my drink from the friendly barista, took a sip and the cashier was nice enough to ask if I liked her recommendation. 

Being there reminded me that I had went in 6 months ago and had such a nice experience that I had meant to write a review and never did. I had the egg and cheese sandwich on foccacia bread that came with a side of fruit (see picture). Everyone at the time was very nice and the guy that brought me my food had gone out of his way to do something for me although I can  no longer remember what it was.

I was surprised to see so many negative reviews from the last few months on here. If you're thinking twice about checking out Quetzal because of those bad reviews, I say ignore the negative nancys and give it a try. It's only coffee. It's not like you're risking the pink slip on your car by trying the place out. I have had nothing but good service and good coffee/food here.
author: Liz M.

description: I was looking for a place to grab a coffee on Polk and found this really nice place! I had a latte and was just perfect : smooth , right temperature: milk wasn't  burnt but it was hot enough. I hate when they make coffee tepid. Surprised by the quality of their coffee, I decided to stay and have something to eat, I was in a hurry so I quickly chose pesto chicken crepe.  Boy! It was delicious and the crepe is huge! I really liked the chicken ,and pesto had delicate but strong flavor.  I am so picky about pesto and I like mine to be perfect and that is how I feel about this one, just perfect taste and texture! Also the price is really amazing! If I am not mistaken it was around 7 bucks ! I never can find a good lunch for under 10! I really really recommend this place! Didn't have time to see the whole menu.   But will be back!
author: Gulya B.

description:
The service was painfully slow, and then the two people at the counter completely disregarded my concern when I realized that a man came in from the street and stole my wallet from my purse (other eyewitnesses noticed the suspicious activity, but we didn't realize what happened until the wallet - and the person - were long gone). I notified the staff and they didn't respond with any concern or help whatsoever. 

I don't blame the business for the criminal activity, but I was really disheartened to see their lack of regard for customers. We were waiting nearly 30 minutes for salads, which is when this occurred, and then the staff did not offer to help, call authorities, or look for the person who came into the restaurant and took my property from my purse. Very disappointed :(

(And yes, the police are now involved... the person has attempted to break into my bank accounts and other accounts for the past several weeks). 

Guard your stuff if you go there. And plan to sit around waiting for a long time.
author: Jax R.

description:
While the staff is nice, the internet is spotty and the food is embarrassingly awful for the price. The nachos were basically just tortilla chips with cheese on them and lazily dabbled sour cream. Where are the beans? Don't get me started on how bad their quesadillas are. These guys should really just give up on the whole psuedo-mexican food thing. They suck at it.

That being said, they have beer and 2 hour wifi. Take it for what you will but don't spend any money on the food. Trust me.
author: Nichole A.

description:
I work in coffee shops a lot and I get really annoyed when I spend one hour settling in a place having my coffee, struggling to connect for half an hour and having to leave all frustrated to find a new coffee shop with WiFi. If you are in the same situation, I hope this review helps you avoid this place at the first stage. Here is why:

The toilets were really dirty as if they haven't been cleaned for a while, I mean days. The atmosphere is boring and it just feels like there is no love put in for the place at all in terms of design, cleanliness...It is indeed an internet coffee with computers and the internet stopped working after half an hour and the staff was not helpful and friendly. They gave me a new ticket to join the network while my browser was not even starting.
author: Duygu G.

description:
I'm going to give Quetzal a 3.5. They have great drinks and smoothies, but their prices are high, and food prep slow. I'm also not a huge fan of the 2 hour wi-fi limit (get your username and password from the register before sitting down to work).

S loves their protein/workout shakes, but they run him $7 every time he hits the gym. Some of the power smoothies look like swamp water and taste like grass - I don't get the appeal, but he sure does chug them after boxing class!
author: Alison C.

description:
Call it a 'first world' problem if you will (I do), but one of THE most annoying situations I can find myself in is entering a cafe with a huge Internet sign on the front, only to find that it is the worst internet I've experienced either in the first or third world.  Seriously.  

You must get a ticket when you purchase, yet there's no sign at the register that informs you of this.  So I go back to ask for a ticket.  He says he needs to get some.  I wait nearly five minutes and then go back to the counter to ask for a ticket -- which the cashier cheerfully handed over.  I sign on and I can't get anything done with the signal apart from deleting unwanted emails.  Really??  And forget about streaming a video (though that's a rare occurrence for me when I'm trying to GET SOME WORK DONE FOR PETE'S SAKE) cause the service tells you straight up -- that won't happen. 

The manager (owner?) seemed less than mildly interested in trying to fix the connection (if that's even possible).    And when I politely said I had to go, he didn't even acknowledge me.  I will never return and strongly advise selecting another of the many cafes in the area.

And Quetzal, tisk-tisk for the false advertising.  An internet cafe, you are not.
author: Sarah N.

description:
They're mean and really  rip customers off.

Wow - what a mean-spirited rip-off business.  Went there late a.m. 10/1/2013.

Firstly, they are insanely expensive.  A sandwich is $12 and a burrito is $15!!!!  Ok, fine.  That's their right, obviously.

I am a vegan.  I asked for no cheese and no cream cheese in my veggie sandwich.  Could they put a bit of avacado instead?  "That'll be extra".  What?  for a $12 sandwich?  That's not reasonable.  Work with me here, especially if you're gouging me for a meagre veggie sandwich.

Later:  Do you have any water? "Yes, bottled only - $2".  No water jug?  After I spent all that on food and coffee?  Wow.  Not coming back here.

There's an ok coffee place with internet on Pine and Polk.  Going there,  Join me.
author: Jed S.

description:
Apparently under new management, this place has good intentions but need some serious help with thier staff. Starting with basic training. They all are pretty clueless. There are four girls and a child standing around without any experience.regrettably, I ordered a crêpe. The girl who tried making it had obviously never been trained in crêpe  making. It was a total disaster, shredded and destroyed, she had to throw it away.  Instead of making another one I asked for my money back. Most places would've offered something in return as an apology, perhaps some coffee or something else on the house... they did not offer anything. It's pretty embarrassing watching them try to figure out how to make a A latte and a coffee house, or food without any training.  Think of the Three Stooges but all girls!
Perhaps the owners will read this review and start training their staff before putting them in front of customers. If you charge money for something you should offer some kind of professional service or product. Maybe we'll stop by in six months to see what you have come up with. Because honestly the ambience is great for working on your computer, and having some food and drink and some nice music. But at this stage bring your own food and drink!
author: Cerraeh L.

description:
This is my first time here, just ordered and a white mocha and bagel with hummus. The white mocha is absolutely delicious, just the way coffee should taste like. The bagel just tasted like a bagel, nothing special. They also serve beer and wine, a coffee shop that serves beer and wine, I am in. 

They also have free wifi for 2 hours, and then you have to order another cup of coffee, which I would have no problem with doing. Wifi is quite fast as well. They also have 9-10 iMacs for those unfortunate few that don't have a laptop. 

The place does have a warehouse feel, not the normal cozy coffee shop, but I got no problem with it if the coffee is good, and it is Great. Do yourself a favor and order the white mocha and satisfy your taste buds with what coffee should taste like.
author: Anuj C.

description:
I'd rather relieve myself in the alley outside than ever step foot in Quetzal's restroom again. They say you can tell the cleanliness of a restaurant's kitchen by looking at how clean they keep their restrooms.  If this is true, I should be spitting out the bagel I was forced to bring home and eat because I couldn't use Quetzal's restroom. 

Why couldn't I use it? Well, because there was a big, hairy-legged man crapping in what used to be the womens' restroom but is now faux-unisex. One restroom with two filthy stalls and UNLOCKABLE. Apparently there is "construction" going on in the mens' room so they just made the womens an unlockable unisex batheroom. My guess is that it's been "under construction" for months. No signs, no aplogies. Just a chaotic, dingy, FILTHY mess. No soap, an array of dirty of paper towels on the floor.  On top of all of that, there is the inhumane process of having to ask the cashier to buzz you into that pit any time you need to use it. I'd put up with that if the bathrooms were private and not festering with bacteria.

And the cherry on top? A grumpy, non-smiling cashier who clearly hates working there as much as I hated being there this morning.  

Quetzal, invest in improving the environment for your customers who are paying quite decently for your food and drink. I highly doubt your restrooms even comply with code. 

If you're craving the adventure of travel to a developing country, but don't have the time or funds, take a whirl through Quetzal's one and only bathroom. You won't be disappointed.
author: Nette J.

description:
Solid coffeehouse. You know, as opposed to all all the liquid coffeehouses out there.

In all seriousness though, this coffee shop has a lot going for it:
- Large menu that includes smoothies and all sorts of bites
- Spacious seating area with some outdoor spots
- Old-school Mac-only workstations, what whaaat?
- Plugs galore
- Free 2-hour Wifi with purchase code - you sneaky bastards...

The lighting is plentiful and ambient. A pleasure to work and hang out here when I'm headed the tender direction.

---

Distinguishing factor: The tea bags are as hipster as you can imagine. They come in a freestanding brown filter bag--very fresh and organic. Get large bowl of tea to complement the hipsterness.
author: Nick A.

description: This place treats everyone who comes in like a criminal. Apparently, they attract a lot of the "street folk" but that's no excuse to presume anyone who comes in is guilty.
author: Dan G.

description:
I have been planning to come here for the longest time after hearing about their wifi connection, organic coffee, excellent macaroons and coffee cake. I finally brought my friend David N. here for a visit this afternoon. 

Ambiance and Service: I was so excited when I finally made my way here. The interior was slick colorful with shades of upbeat yellow and soothing orange to compliment plenty of nice looking plants. Initially I wanted to add this cafe to my regular line up of places to hang out, but my experience turned out sour and disappointing. While I was actively looking to find their macaroons and coffee cake which they later told me they had ran out, their male servers were very rude and impatient. One of them became very upset with me when I was in the process of choosing my drink, and rather than helping me with an introduction with what was good here, he stood there looking annoyed. The nice female server had to calm him down and made some suggestions which I thought was helpful.

Dessert and Drink: I thought her recommended mixed fruit pie was solid, but the iced soy mocha was not well made at all. The drink was culminated by un-dissolved chocolate powder clumped at the bottom like a landfill that prompted a rough grainy finish. In retrospect, these alternative desserts along with the poor service were not enough to dissuade my disappointment for missing out on the two things I came for, the macaroons and coffee cake.

Wifi:  Contrary to Neil S. and Kristine W's reviews, their internet was not free during my visit, but 16 cents per minute according to their staff. As soon as that was said, I realized that I really don't have a purpose for being here so decided to pack up my laptop and quickly made my exit. 

What a waste of time and effort! Contrary to other reviews, my visit was stressful and unpleasant. I won't be going out of my way to come here again.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Nice quaint coffee place. 

Straight up you get what you ask for. No frills or fluff or bs.
author: One L.

description:
For years, I was a regular at Quetzal, but since new management took over, I can no longer recommend it.

It's no longer clean (the restrooms, in particular, are quite unpleasant). The food is not nearly as tasty. The prices have gone up. And the staff are far less friendly. Too bad.
author: Solange M.

description: This place is dirty, dirty, dirty. It's seating was set up by someone who either doesn't care, does t know how to do it, or both. Why would you ask the customer if it's for here or to go if you don't want the them to stay? I made the mistake of saying "for here". An unkempt messy haired individual served me a colder attitude than my strawberry & Nutella crepe was. It was in a to go container and the utensils I was given were so cheap and flimsy, they were literally unusable. I called "excuse me!" To catch the servers attention and he look at me, smiled, then walked away. I walked over to him and I politely asked for a normal set of utensils. I explained that the ones given to me were terrible and he smiled again saying "I know". RUDE!!
author: Jackie K.

description:
Back in January, they had this great, yummy smoked salmon with fried egg sandwich with a side of fruit. I went back today and it wasn't on the menu anymore. So sad!! :(:(:( So they recommended this salmon burger ($12) which is actually pretty good but its not the same. 

I'll definitely be back to try their other breakfast items tho. Everything looks so tempting. Their items are a little on the pricey side but at least its worth it every once in awhile.

They have a patio/seating space that used to be a parking space so its great spot to sit down and enjoy a cup of coffee.
author: Jean T.

description: I've been here several times and with each time I enjoy this place more and more. I love their crapes and my husband is a fun of sandwiches! During the day you can enjoy tasty cup of coffee or tea and a bit later in a day you can relax with glass of wine or a beer. Selection is pretty good as well. They have indoor and outdoor seats which is perfect with the kind of weather we experiencing now. Perfect place to study  or meet with a friends for a brunch. Oh and they have a TV so you can follow your team (go Giants) :) And of course the people who work here make this place special. Always friendly and helpful!
author: Anastasia S.

description:
Quetzal is relatively close to where I'm currently staying, so I'm bound to wind up in there again, at least in passing.  But, by and large, this place is not all that great.

I first visited Quetzal in March of 2012 during a visit to San Francisco.  I stopped in to get a smoothie (the vegan and non-vegan options were great) and use their internet.  Over the course of my week long visit I stopped in there one more time and had a pleasant experience with both the staff and their product.  I thought the place was great.

Fast forward 9 months and I've officially moved to San Francisco.  One of my first stops was, of course, Quetzal.  I'm an avid coffee drinker and I often telecommute for work, so a favorite local coffee spot is a nice thing to have.  However, in the interim since I had last been there, something seems to have gone to shit.  

While their drinks have remained great, their customer service had taken a serious nose dive.  They close at random times, don't keep regular business hours, and routinely made me wait for my drink while they prepared an easier one for someone standing in line behind me.  That, and their buzz-you-into-the-bathroom set up is just ridiculous.  I know they must get a lot of non-paying walk-ins trying to use the bathroom, so I get putting some kind of lock on it, but that just isn't working out.  Also, whoever is buzzing them in from the counter is often mumbling under their breath while they do it.  

I've always enjoyed the beer they have on tap there and their abundant supply of electrical outlets near their tables, but I don't know that I ever see myself returning.
author: Mario B.

description: I've come here a few times a week to get research done as I settle into San Francisco. It offers a great combo: music, tasty lattes, better food than you would except for a cafe, and WiFi that actually works! Keep it up, Quetzal. :)
author: Aisha R.

description: I came late at night as my hotel up the road was noisy and very uninteresting. The place is big, serves a good variety of drinks, but the telly was on all the time and I found that somewhat annoying. Great place if you can work with the telly in the background. The tea and hot chocolate we had were good.
author: Tatiana K.

description: Large place with nice outdoor seating. Only problem is the legion of homeless people that squat here with ease.
author: Alex B.

description: Language problem communication; don't understand half of the order. The food is ok. It looks nicer than it is.
author: Vincent S.

description: I really try to support local businesses in the area instead of going to the big guys like Starbucks and Peet's but, this trip was not good.  I came in and order a beverage which was fine.  Later, I went to the counter to order food and waited at least 10 minutes because someone was on the phone and doing something to the register. Your paying customers should always come first.  Put the person on the phone on hold and conduct their business after your customers have been taken care of.  I couldn't tell if they were putting in a supply order or what.  I finally order a Zesty Burrito.  It was brought out to me and looked okay at first.  I was brought condiments that were almost empty.  Fill your ketchup, salt, and pepper etc.  This is such an easy fix.  I came in the morning so there is no excuse to give me empty ketchup bottles and not wipe off he tops. Next, I notice my burrito is missing 3 of the 9 ingredients.  When I return to the counter, the cashier argues with me that it is only one missing ingredient.  Well, why is it missing anything in the first place.  The cashier clearly does not know how to deal with customers.  The cook came out and didn't seem to say much.  Either he doesn't know the menu, or he was making it the way he wanted. I then point out the ingredients on the signs behind them on the huge billboard.  He realizes there is stuff missing and tells me they are out of the beans, but they can add avocado and the salsa.  Well, should't you tell me before I order that you are out of something?  It happens.  Restaurants run out of things but, be up front and don't serve me something I ordered with three things missing after I pay for something.  Then, I decided that after this guy argued with me, I don't want to reorder, they seemed to be irritated that I wanted my money back.  Honestly, I just didn't want the cook to spit in my food.  It wasn't until another person (from the back) came out that there was an actual apology given to me.  This is service 101 people.  If you screw up just apologize and move on but don't argue, then get an attitude because I asked for my money back.  If you are out of something just tell me and be honest.  I was polite and told them I would try them again but, I'll only be ordering drinks from now on.
author: J M.

description:
I really like this cafe. There are a lot of tables (that are cleaned regularly), their tea is delicious and well-priced, the staff is nice, it's relatively quiet, they take credit cards and don't have some irritating minimum purchase amount, they have free wi-fi, and they're open relatively late. What's not to like?

Next time I have a long stint of working from home, this will be the place I go to get some work done and get out of the house.
author: Dani D.

description:
Quetzal serves both delicious coffee and great sandwiches, and sells reasonably priced coffee (buy a pound and they'll give you a free coffee as part of the bargain).  Street side seating is abundant and in this particular neighborhood there is plenty to watch and ponder, as you might guess.  Free wifi inside and out  is also a nice plus, but if the weather doesn't accommodate, there is ample seating inside.  

(Just don't ask me where the quetzal name comes from ... there wasn't much Mexican about this place!)
author: Vince V.

description:
All you need to know: Breakfast pizza. Seriously. 

Eggs, lox on a soft pizza bread. Heaven. 

See: http://flickr.com/photos/calmenda/2268913183/

Lauren hates lox and this thing was awesome. It was only $7 and could easily feed two. Her fritata was also huge. I would definitely suggest sharing. 

The space is nice and the staff were very friendly. I was going to share my smoothie and he offered to give us two cups, which I thought was a nice gesture. 

I think they're going for the whole andean / "we do fair trade" theme. It's a great roomy space. They also have free wi-fi and computers that you can use. 

There is NO doubt that I will be going back .
author: Carlos A.

description: Excellent breakfast for a quick bite in the morning. Open on MLK Day, definitely a plus! Service is friendly!
author: Robert G.

description: So disturbed, had to write a review. Came here just to check the place out. Had decent yelp reviews so thought would give it a try. Whiles settling my things down--went up to ask for wi-fi and was told "No." I get that I have to buy something first--but talk about very poor customer service! Definitely won't be coming back here again. Thankfully other cafes in area to check out. Also--couldn't help but include--I'm an African American female and wondered if this came into play...sad.
author: Madeline N.

description:
Bought a sloppy job chicken sandwich and a whole salad plus a medium iced tea for $24 dollars?! 

I can make that sandwich better; in fact, I know and can and will. Idk if the dudes working that time were just too lazy to make a decent and respectable chicken sandwich on a Friday night, but I bought those sammiches at 9 pm. You usually go out at 11 ish on a Friday night in sf, so they have no reason to be so butthurt that they don't put any effort in making me a sammich.

Hell, I work in a cafe, and our prices are 1/3-2/3 of their prices, and our food is crafted better.
author: Colleen J.

description:
The staff here are so basic... I just can't with them! My order is always wrong, the baristas are always clueless and/or rude, and they always screw up my change (like, always... are they intentionally trying to steal from customers?). Every. Single. Time. I really, really, tried to like this place - it's a great spot, physically. 
After my last trip, the service was so awful I vowed never to come back, but I have a soft spot to local coffee shops and thought I'd give them one last try. It just reminded me how much I hate this place. My order was screwed up (yet again), they tried to gyp me on my change (yet again) and then acted like giving me their internet password was giving me the codes for a nuclear weapon (again). I seriously think you have to be demonstrably stupid to be hired here. 
I've learned my lesson this time. I'll never go back. Which is a shame - such a nice space gone to waste.
author: Adam R.

description:
Well... I used to like it here. Lots of space, lots of outlets. Perfect place to get work done on my laptop between clients. Wayne, the previous manager always called out to me by first name and new my order instantly. He kept the register well stocked with dollar coins so when my meter card ran out, (because of course Polk street still hasn't updated the parking meters) I could count on being able to keep the meter maid at bay. It was a great haven. 
That was then, this is now. I've come here since the new management took over and the guy barely remembers me. The "free wifi" boots you off after about 30 seconds. I've wasted an hour here on three separate occasions trying to get online. Feel like a sucker at this point. Classic case of losing good business through incompetent management. Not coming here again. Brewing my coffee at home, and taking my internet needs to the place up the block. If you like being ignored and trying in vain to get wifi, by all means, hit this place up. Otherwise, there's like a thousand better places on Polk St.
author: Albert I.

description: I used to like the Quetzal, it used to be a busy place but if you look at their photos, they show the food, but, their prices are exuberantly high now.  They've always been a bit higher then any other coffee place around. Would you pay $18.50 for a vegetarian burrito. Watching a ball game the owner who is probably Muslim or Arab, comes in and shuts the game on to put on the music from where he comes. This tells you where his priorities are at, definitely,  not with his customers.  Too bad it was a good place before, not any longer!
author: George T.

description:
The weather is gorgeous, I'm certainly not going to stay inside. One of those rare days the heat arrives early making you want to do anything as long as it's outdoors. I head to Quetzal for this exact reason, with outdoor tables, a little pie and a pot of tea ought to be just perfect. 

My order is ready and I realize I can't possibly carry pie, tea pot, mug and silverware all in one trip. I figure to drop the pie off outside and run back in for the tea, I'll be gone all of 20 seconds, my pie will surely be safe. I glance left and right, no one heading my pie's direction, now is the chance. Back in a flash yet sure enough I return to find a man sitting at my table, hovering over my pie.

"Is this your pie?" he asks. "Indeed it is and I have to admit I'm quite impressed, I was gone 15 seconds. Were you hiding behind a car or something? Maybe a convicted pie stalker?"

"Man... I was about to tear that pie UP. I was waitin', but man you had about 30 more seconds, no lie." Customers at another table found it rather amusing.

Off he jogs, thankfully my pie untouched. I pour a cup of perfectly steeped organic hojicha and settle in to relax, alternating between Pandora stations, a little 60s Reggae and then some Chet Baker. A police officer rides by on a bike, where was he to serve and protect my pie? Even a stolen slice of pie wouldn't have ruined the beautiful day, it's the most relaxed I've been in weeks. 

I love places like Quetzal for these unique yet restful days. A classy cafe, catering with teas and vegan pie as well as standard coffee and breakfast fare. Things of the Nob Hill type, yet a location still complete with the colorful and always exciting passersby from the Tenderloin. The staff here are chatty and friendly, and should I be a little more wise I'm positive they'd assist me with extra hands so I need not leave my delicious pie unsupervised. 

I sat outside for an hour or two, just enjoying life. Well, enjoying life along with the pie and tea to be precise. My visit ended with the approach of a man, a touch dirty and I'm certain he's going to ask for change. I explain I have no cash and his face shows shock, it turns out he merely wanted to show me a magic trick. I have to say sleight of hand or not I was impressed, and with a tip of the hat he was on his way. A perfect end to a perfect visit, a unique experience all thanks to Quetzal.
author: Justin N.

description: What is the tip for? They ask for a tip on the screen during the check out process,  I tipped 20% when I ordered.  What a waste of money.  I ordered a burrito and a latte for breakfast.  They brought me the burrito after 10 minutes but still no coffee.   Hello! It's 8am, where's my coffee? That should have been first priority.  I went back to the counter after my food was delivered and had to ask for it again  and take it to the table myself only to discover that it is cold.   The burrito was very watery and left a pool of tomato juice dripping out the bottom.   No hotsauce on the tables and none to even offer except for some crappy sauce she poured me out of a bulk jug from the food supply warehouse.  Hello!? You are serving burritos and hash Browns for breakfast and you don't have Tobacco or Cholula?? This place needs a new manager to come in and fix up the problems because it is a great space in a great location,  but the service is lacking,  a lot.
author: Stephen L.

description: Sitting at Quetzal using the internet and it freezes - seems like it's been hacked (I've been hacked  before).  I ask the older, ponytailed guy behind the counter for help and he comes over.  I explain the situation and he just smirks and says that problem is between me and the computer.  Seriously?!?  Passwords and private information have been typed into this machine and not only could he care less but he doesn't even TRY to help.  I live around the corner and just started coming here (while my hacked computer is being fixed) but I will never come back again! This place sucks!
author: Q M.

description: On this visit I had no issues with the Internet. And they're now playing 80s hits with no ads. Awesome :)
author: Harry M.

description:
Iced Americano, super legit.  And for $2, can't really beat it.  You'll notice immediately that they make em right, because they lightly pour the espresso over the ice, not drop it in.  The result is this nice caramel creamy layer on top. YUM!!!  Also, it's probably the biggest americano I've seen for $2...
On another visit, my friends and I consumed a pitcher of sangria.  They claimed its pretty strong and is made using the same recipe as cha cha cha (whatever that means...)  It wasn't bad, but seemed more like just red wine and simple syrup.
I'd like to come back to try some of their real food, but I'd suggest passing on the blueberry muffins.  They look good, but only tastes ok, if even that.
author: Christopher L.

description: Friendly nice, big, breakfast creps looks so good! Good for study. Not good for dates ;)
author: Seda G.

description:
Wow, a cafe that got it ALL right.

Free WIFI - with PLENTY of outlets
Good lighting
Large, comfortable seating with large tables/ workspaces
Long line of iMacs if you're not a laptop person
Reasonable prices
Large selection of teas (sorted by caffeine amount in bags or pots)
Frequent buyers club-- 10% off purchase when you sign up, then a discount after every $12 spent
Vegan friendly with baked goods, soy options
Fast friendly service
Clean restrooms 
Unobtrusive background music
Accept Visa or Mastercard
Large selection of good quality cafe food if you need more than a snack (with plenty of vegan/ vegetarian options! yes!)
Local coffee

Love this place. Wish there was one in the East Bay too! :)
author: Debora L.

description:
All life is change and Quetzal has changed too much, and I still give glory to the Messenger Alah
They forgot their innate goodness, the women workers are not appreciated as much as before and LBGTQ people well you go and decide for your selves.  Yet if you have lived in this neighborhood for over 40 years, like me and you go in and get sad.

Peace and All Good
author: Timoty G.

description: Quetzal used to be a good place to spend some time on the Internet, but it seems to have gone downhill recently. New management? The music is now too loud to concentrate. The "freshly squeezed" orange juice used to be just that, now it's been sitting in the fridge cabinet long enough for the pulp to be a separate layer. The outside seats seem to be new, so new when we visited that the varnish hadn't dried properly. There need to be more power receptacles, although this is a common problem with Internet cafes. On the plus side the staff were friendly and helpful, the food adequate and the coffee is good by SF standards. And there's always a seat. Needs improvement.
author: Greg B.

description:
http://www.quetzal.org

I had coffee at this store. It was good coffee, grimey store, food blah! I tried to order from their website and call them. You cannot reach this store via phone and my order of coffee has been stuck on processing over two weeks. I wrote emails, no response. Seriously, take your useless website down.
author: ANESA B.

description: It's really disrespectful & demeaning to joke about homelessness with all your blind privilege. To say on your image of the out door seating " bums dominating the outdoor seating" is beyond horrible in so many ways.
author: Concerned Community Member C.

description:
I can't Quet you Quetzal....

A friend recommended this place to me today and I am glad he did.  Great menu, eclectic drinks and friendly staff.  This is my idea of what a coffee shop should be...minus the occasional Megan's Law internet user.

Great selection of teas and I will definitely try the food next time.
author: Brian S.

description:
This is a nice local cafe with good coffee and great service. Most guests seem to go here for using their computers or for studying, so I wouldn't say its the good-to-café if you wanna socialize. Opening hours are quite good, they close ~10pm. So I usually end up going here when other cafes nearby have closed, and I need to get some work done.
