The only drawback is that the Internet connection seem to be kinda slow, so go somewhere else if speed is important to you.
author: Niklas A.

description:
Great food selection but REALLY slow for hot prepared foods, so don't try to order that on the go! 

Wish they didn't have the pesky 2 hour limit for internet - no other cafe does it! Seating is also really uncomfortable though the Macs for public use are convenient.
author: Amy M.

description: This is a really nice, local cafe with a ton of seating and big windows for plenty of natural light. There's also seating outside on the sidewalk if you want to soak up some sunshine. The savory crepes are crisp and tasty, and the coffee is decent. I like it for the space more than the food, especially as a place to work and write.
author: Jessica L.

description:
My personal Yelping philosophy is that five star ratings don't mean that whatever is the most expensive version of whatever it is you're talking about. To me, each of those precious stars twinkling scarlet and orange in the Yelpiverse reflects how perfectly a business captures its purpose.

Example: Sticky counters at a dive bar = bonus star; sticky counters at a Michelin rated restaurant = minus star(s); sticky counters at a strip club = par for the course.

This brings me to Quetzal, which completely satisfies what it sets out to be and therefore deserves five stars.

1. pretty good coffee (fair trade, organic, decently made, delicious even)
2. Lots of plugs! Nothing worse than going to a coffee shop with ample seats, tasty drinks, generous free wifi and only two plugs. *shakes fist* You know who you are.
3. Lots of room. I hate the vulture culture that develops in coffee shops with limited seating. You know, the old scan the room and swoop at the first sign of fresh meat (or an about-to-be-open seat).
4. computers for people without laptops (you have to pay of course)
5. Open pretty late

And you can people watch if you need a mental break. Neat exposed concrete at some points. This is my new I need to get out of the house to work on stuff oasis. Also, one of my delights is learning the new wifi password. It changes every day. Examples of some I have gotten: verisimilitude and existential.

I believe they also serve beer for when you have really had enough of whatever crap you're working on. Man... that is priceless.
author: Jess C.

description:
I love this cafe! It has very unique drinks and food. Pleasant background music and nice atmosphere. The staff is very friendly and... cute ;) 

Make sure you try Moan-A-Latte! My favorite!!! :)
author: Vitåliiå V.

description: Nice baristas, chill environment for bringing your laptop (free WIFI) or getting some reading done, and awesome coffee. I love strong coffee, and they use 2 shots of espresso for their small, so i was pretty satisfied with my latte. Their cookies are really good, they even heated it up for us so that the chocolate was gooey to perfection. Found my new go-to coffee shop!
author: Angela K.

description: Terrible service, dirty dining room, ok quality and price. I ordered eggs and waited nearly a half hour for them to come. There was hardly anyone else there this Sunday. (Maybe that should have been a sign?) When I went to check the counter person gave me some attitude and discovered the order had "just been finished." Maybe all the dirty, empty tables meant they just had a rush and the rest of the staff were taking a break? I live in this neighborhood and have been looking for a good breakfast place to frequent. Quetzal is not it.
author: Greg J.

description:
Every time I come in theres a lovely crew working, and I get my bagel(s) and coffee fast and it's delicious. Definitely sign up for a customer number I always get some sweet deal. They're awesome and will always come back. 
 ps
Mona has worked there for as long as Ive been coming, always has a smile on her face and does some pretty bomb foam art. 
Thanks Quetzal for making my day
author: Chauntae M.

description: Great breakfast burrito. Very filling and delicious. A little pricier than I expected though ~$14
author: Alex S.

description: Like a lot of people on a weekday I was looking for a spot to park to get some work done all day. This place was a dream come true...for the first 45 minutes. And then they turned on the big screen tv and played some soccer game at full volume. I thought the only did that at bars? Will not be going back.
author: Jeannie D.

description:
Ehhhhh.  You are better off going to any other cafe in the city.

The food here is overpriced and extremely poor.  Their $12+ salads taste like they are made from all canned ingredients.

Their coffee is poor as well.  I am not a coffee connoisseur by any means, but I know for a fact that the coffee I had here today was the worst coffee experience of my life.

They make you pay for internet.  Yeah, you have to buy their overpriced food and drinks for their internet that cuts out frequently.

It's cold as hell in here and it's like 75 degrees outside and all the doors are open.  I don't know how they manage this one, but I'm not surprised.

If you want an amazing cafe a few blocks away, give Angel Cafe a try.
author: Javin L.

description: Don't drink the coffee.  Free trade my ass.  If you want a good cup of coffee, dont come here!
author: John T.

description:
Computer table is filthy and wi-fi
slow and sporadic.  I prefer better
service than a smile from the barista.  
Expect to buy an item every 2 hours to have WiFi.
author: Michael F.

description: Great place to come in for a Latte. They are best served for inside instead of to in take-away cups. My favourite Barista works here - Mona. I have been coming to Quetzal since moving to SF in 2011. Its gone through changes. I have always loved their coffees & their internet wifi is super fast and convenient! I really like the plants inside and the garden/patio piece that has been built outside. The owners have changed and Im not sure that I would keep coming here if it weren't for Mona and her beautiful coffees. But this is a convenient place to pop in for coffee or tea if you live in Nob Hill, TL, or close to Polk Street! Lots of seating, I have eaten here a few times, nothing memorable about the food. But this place is decent when you want something that is an alternative to Starbucks, Peets, La Boulange, etc... oh & of course they've always had lightning fast Wifi to boot.
author: Julian I.

description:
I went here today and had one of the worst customer experiences Ive had in a long time.

Around 3 pm I was meeting a random person here for a craigslist transaction. Not wanting to seem rude (and being thirsty), I ordered a smoothie. I told the guy twice what I wanted (a medium "wayne"), we get to the register and the guy says "Large wayne right?" in one of those phony cute upsale suggestion voices. I didnt find it cute at all as im not trying to spend 10 bucks on a smoothie, I gave him my order twice and he's just playing stupid games and wasting my time. As I was paying another guy chimes in with "Wayne likes to be well tipped" in a really douchy tone...i guess my dollar tip wasnt enough. After I got my drink, I realized he had charged me for two. I went back to the counter where another medium smoothie sat. I told him Id been overcharged, he countered with "Your friend ordered one.". As I wasnt in line with anyone that would be impossible and I told him as much. After 30 seconds of more ridiculousness, he told me he'd give me a refund but he himself would have to pay for the extra mystery upsell smoothie. Was it supposed to be like a guilt trip or something? Im not certain but I collected my money and left, never to return to this place. The worst part is the stupid smoothie I bought tasted as bland as could be...I gave it to a homeless guy who took a drink, spat it out and threw the remainder against the side of Hemlock.
author: Michael G.

description:
(See pics)

I was recommended to this place from a few folks who also frequent Caffe Roma. Takes one to know one!

They have a fantastic selection of coffee, smoothies, iced drinks, a good selection of hot and cold sandwiches, soup and salad, pizza and an attractive selection cakes including Hungarian Coffee cake, almond plum cakes, etc. etc.

I came here around 5-ish pm to have my brunch and had the Randy Baby (chicken breast and turkey with Jack cheese and a side salad) and a Caramel Latte. I picked the food because I know a Randy who is very cool! Good food and very filling. The coffee was impressive.

Really glad to find a cafe with a strip of electrical outlets along the bench with pretty good wifi!! It's a fantastic place to do work on their sizable tables and very background style music. People over there are friendly and relaxed.

It would be so easy to sit here, eat and work all day!
author: T L.

description:
For me, Quetzal is the cafe equivalent of a bad boyfriend that you keep finding reasons to go back to when you know you shouldn't because it'll just end badly.

I live and work very close to this spot, and a friend of mine raved about the food and coffee and internet. So I checked it out the first time, and got a bagel with hummus, tomato, and cucumber. I could only get half of it down, that hummus quite frankly tasted and looked like baby poop. I've worked in the food service industry a lot so I really try not to knock stuff that harsh, but I'm Greek and that hummus made me one sad Hellenic.

Also: $4 for a maybe-12-oz cup of fresh-squeezed OJ? Suck it, that is not cool.

So why did I go back? Because I realized they have a wider menu than the baby poo hummus, I always like to give places a second chance, and I'm an orange juice snob and haven't found another outlet for fresh-squeezed in my new 'hood yet.

Got the Quetzal frittata the second time and it was actually really good, just HUGE. HUGE! The size of the plate! Luckily, I love giving my leftovers away to homeless people, and this one was very well received; I found the to-go box totally empty on a curb an hour after I gave it away. Still felt robbed (EVERYTHING is stupid overpriced), especially while I sipped my OJ extra slow to try to make the $4 last.

Then I needed to use a computer since my laptop bought the farm, and so back to Quetzal I went, because I was hungry too and figured hey, two birds with one stone. Decided to try the cobb salad this time and asked about the public computers....they're 16 cents a minute. 16 cents a minute? Who the hell came up with that? That is such a random amount to me. And why, when all of your food and drink are overpriced out the a*s, would you still be charging on public computers when you're a 20 minute walk from the main public library? So I just sadly paid $17 for a salad and my OJ (yes, you heard me) and did the research that preceeded my computer use. The dressing on the salad was way too thick and intense, I frankly couldn't finish it, not even half, and I wasn't even about to give it to a homeless person because it seemed mean.

The one thing I will give Quetzal is they have a very nice sitting area and lots of windows, and I dig that. Also, some of their employees are super nice. But then there's this one chick with black hair who is seriosly rude as sh*t, she's been there the past two times I went and if she's in there next time I seriously will go somewhere else. I like the older guy and the younger blond dude, but that chick with the black hair, man....not cool.

So basically, I will probably go back to Quetzal, but I'm really going to try not to for a while because quite frankly I can't afford them. And there's plenty of better coffee shops in the Tenderloin that don't make you feel like you've just been backhanded across the face after you pay.
author: Kyveli S.

description: Edited Review: Gave this place another chance. . . and things have certainly change for the better. Very happy now.  :D
author: Audrey S.

description: As far as internet cafes go, it's middle of the road. As with almost every establishment in SF (especially Nob Hill), it is overpriced. However, the staff is very friendly and accommodating. The wifi is regularly down though, which can be a problem. The food is okay. Not the best.
author: Jason K.

description:
Stopped into Quetzal recently for a caffeine fix and quick lunch after a long flight into the city.   The place seemed nice enough as I had been there a few years earlier.  Their blended beverages are good and fit the bill.  The Near Death and Heaven were both well made and were quite the pick up needed to get thru the afternoon.  

We also got a Hummus sandwich which came with a side salad to split.  When the staff delivered the sandwich, he realized we were going to share and said he'd be right back with another plate - but never returned.  The Hummus sandwich was good enough and the salad was a nice blend.  Cheers.
author: G M.

description: Def my favorite neighborhood coffee shop! They have freshly squeezed orange juice that is amazing too!
author: Jared L.

description:
I've only been working in the area for about a week and a half and I've already become a patron of Quetzal 3 times!! I am absolutely in love with their Chai Soy Latte - so creamy with the right amount of sweetness and spice. It is a perfect pick me up during my breaks. 

I also tried their veggie sandwich- generously stuffed with artichoke hearts, lettuce, and sun dried tomatoes on a soft focaccia bread- comes with a side salad. Though on the expensive side (came out to $9) for a vegetarian sandwich it packed flavored punch! 

The pastries do not look that appetizing though, they look as if they've been sitting there for quite awhile, sadly begging for some hungry desperate soul to purchase them. 

I haven't gotten a chance to stay and enjoy the space, but it seems like a great place to get some work on or read the newspaper. Outside they line the sidewalk with seats, I love the additional colorful "patio" that extends out into the street! 

*Definitely sign up for a "customer number" if you plan to come here a lot, they keep track of how many times you come here and give you customer rewards!!
author: Eva H.

description:
Quetzel is a little bit of a walk from my place but I used to come here a lot. Mostly, for the smoothies and shakes. Yummy and healthy!

The breakfast pizza w/ lox and eggs was really good too.  They have wifi too. 

It's a win-win!
author: Lauren C.

description: Pretty overpriced, same as other places within this area. I got the Quetzal sandwich and it was ok. The bread was a bit soggy and tasted weird, everything inside it was good. The coffee was decent as well but nothing over the top. I haven't tried the sweets and it seems like they have a variety so might try those next time. The crepes sound really good.
author: Marlo M.

description:
OK so this place is cool because it has a lot of space, Internet and some cool art on the walls-- but it is a rip off. The staff is nice but the few times I've been here they have been really slow and unaware of the menu.

The coffee is good, but it cost me nearly $6 for a large iced chai with a shot of espresso (dirty chai) ? It also cost me $10 for one of the worst 8inch pizza's I have ever had. I like to $1 Tostino pizzas I used to eat in college better. It wasn't cooked all the way, the ingredients I can promise aren't fresh or organic like the menu promised, and to top it off they don't even have parmesan cheese. NO PARMESAN cheese and you're trying to sell me a $10 little pizza that contains the worst tasting sauce and cheese I have experienced in awhile. 

Enough said. Don't eat here if you're poor, nothing is under $10 unless you want a cup of soup or a cookie. Also, don't get the pizza but perhaps other menu items are better.
author: Krista N.

description: Spacious, offers decent coffee, good beer deals on tap, and curb side patio seating...that's all I can say positively. Otherwise, WiFi did not work although it was free. There was a group of flies congregating around the front door and register. An exterminator was working on site midday. The bathroom, which is not in line of sight of the register counter, must be unlocked from the register. This required two trips on a double-level ramp to let the cashier know the door wasn't open. (To be fair, she had a line of people and she was serving alone.) But the bathrooms themselves were disgusting - smelling of wet dog, cold, damp, dark (the second light bulb was out), then i found a lady camping out in a stall, changing, with the door open. The venue is huge, but if you're in here during the day you'll be blinded by the sun that comes in: There's only one working sunshade  blocking a window with no sun; the window with sun had no shade to make room for a neon beer sign. This place also has an identity crisis - it's an internet cafe, turned brunch restaurant, turned sports bar. I'm never visiting again.
author: Liz C.

description:
Quetzal is either, a ramp to the restroom, converted into a coffee shop. Or it is a small business seriously screwed over by the American Disabilities Act.

Quetzal has hands down, the best setup for laptop usage on Polk street. A nice environment, and okay music. Until the night when they blast it. Yet the coffee and serving setup is a bid awkward, where people pay, receive drinks, and cream and sugar their coffee in the same tight spot.

Staff is friendly, even when you have to ask them to buzz you into the bathroom constantly. 

This business is a complete anomaly. Sometimes I feel they are actively trying to get rid of customers. The reason why I say this, when it is cold out, they are blowing the fans with the door open. They use a software called Antemedia to regulate their internet users. I understand a business point to do so, and I do not mind buying something every couple hours. Seriously this software is a disaster, and the main reason why I stopped frequenting this place. When you cannot log in, or you get consistent messages telling you, your password is invalid. Free Wi-Fi (is pointless if you cannot use it.

Also avoid the carrot cake.
author: Mark Q.

description:
Pros
Iced Americano was good.
Outdoor seating and sports television without the expectation of getting drunk


Cons
Salmon burger was disappointing only because I paid for and they didn't have avocado (told me when they delivered the sando)
Internet not accessible wirelessly for me and other patrons.


.
author: Andres G.

description:
After our breakfast, niece and I walked around the dirty strip of Polk St. and landed at one of many coffee shops, but one of my favorite on that area and street. 

I was first introduced to the café's White Mocha by a yelper when I was still learning how to yelp. Now that yelper is at the very end of my friend's list and I hope she is doing well. 

Normally, I would infrequently drink a White Mocha. But we had an abrupt thirst for that White Mocha and every coffee shop has their own version and ways of brewing the popular espresso drink. But here, all the coffee and espresso drinks are made from organic fair-ground blend. 

I bought a White Mocha and Niece opted for the Caramel Mocha. For $3.80 each, the barista grinds the freshest beans to prepare our respected beverages. Both of our 16oz drinks also comes with "mountain-size" heaping of fattening whipped cream, and her caramel mocha comes with a drizzle of the caramel on top of the clouded cream. Her drink can be mistaken for a gourmet dessert from a fancy restaurant. When we first sip our drinks, we get a piece of whipped cream from our beverage on the tip of our nose (sorry, no pictures). We also split a Blueberry Scone for $2.25. I'm also not a scone-guy, but that pastry was surprisingly very moist and show no taste of aridity. We enjoyed our treat in the lounge area with comfortable sofas and lounge chairs.

Credit cards are accepted here. And being an internet café, they do have Wi-Fi access (duh!) with both Apple and Internet Explorer. They also have a frequent buyer's card: buy 10 drinks, get the 11th free!
author: Matt G.

description:
Amour 

My coffee lover in the guise of a large white paper cup filled to the brim with something strong, hot and steaming.  

When I'm in this neighborhood, which is almost every weekend, I find the intimate urge to step in to this cute slightly Bohemian (think Au Coquelet in Berkeley) Internet cafe for my orgasmic shot of the day.  It has gotten to the point where the barista's glazed look takes on a slight sparkle of recognition whenever I order my double cap.  Add in the occasional slice of chocolate pound cake or the banana strawberry strudel.....

In addition to offering a warm environment for street escapees, the establishment is quiet and serves to a variety of folk plugged in the virtual world as well as their iPods.  Buy your stuff and everyone leaves you alone.  I've purchased several pounds of the caffeinated love potion here and it leaves a a scented reminder in my car of those recent trysts.

In addition, I'd like to extend my thanks to W for introducing me to this place, because now I will hit this place even during a massive downpour for my fix.

Liquid affairs.  

Les dangereux  ;o)
author: Miika M.

description:
You haven't experienced shaky tables unless you have been to Quetzal. 

You have been warned, bearer of full cups without a lid.

Coffee's decent though, though their latte could be a tad hotter.

Didn't try their WiFi - I prefer to actually talk to friends at a coffee shop. 

Novel idea, I know. Try it out some time.
author: Roland A.

description: I've been coming here for years and have enjoyed using the "park bench" area that was a new addition in the last few years, in addition to the regular tables and chairs against the side of the building. Twice in the last week, I have attempted to use the outdoor seating, but there was leftover plates of food and filth all over the tables and pidgeons hovering over the area to consume the leftovers and generally wreaking havoc with the consumables. I made an attempt on my own to clean up the mess the first time, and told the staff that I was aware that they could be busy, but that they needed to keep tabs on this as this presented a health hazard, especially with pidgeon feces on the chairs and tables. Apologies were exchanged by one of the female staff members, but no one came out to clean the areas. Today (monday), I was here again, and wanted to have a beverage, but the tables were all filthy and there was the usual plates and cutlery and glasses sitting on tables for a long period of time, and pidgeons converging on leftover crepes and salmon. It was disgusting. The straw that "broke the proverbial camel's back" was that one of the pidgeon's defecated on my arm and my leg as I was trying to shoo them away from the area. They tend to lurk above in the girders and wait for leftover food to be left by previous customers. This establishment never seems to clean the tables or make a vigil of clearing them. It's disgusting and the health department should be contacted..
author: Timothy L.

description:
I only had their sandwich once and it was very yummy!

Their iced coffees WITH whipped cream are the highlight of my school days. My school is just across the alley and I come here often. My favorites are the iced vanilla mocha and the chocolate overload. their hot chocolates are great too. Quetzal increased my the caffeine tolerance. Starbuck's coffee pales compared to this place. Their whip cream, I find, more sweeter and thicker (the best!)
author: Alisa M.

description: Food is good. A large group of us came in and the servers got overwhelmed and became disorganized. Take a deep breath people! There are only 10 of us, ordering smoothies, salads, burritos, crepes, and then needing extra plates, to know where coffee cream is... You know, normal stuff. The servers are happy again now that we are eating. The owners should bring a couple of tour busses through here to get these people trained.
author: Naomi W.

description:
Good selection of teas, and the outlets are plentiful. I've also met some fairly interesting people in passing there.

Would be five stars if Wi-Fi wasn't limited to 2 hours.
author: Irene M.

description: I've, once again, gave the relatively new MGMT at Quetzal another try. And, yet again, I was charged a completely different (and more expensive) price for the same friggin' order. Also, from another new employee (amongst the constantly rotating staff) I receive "attitude" when I question pricing. Consistency is key for both repeat customers and those who choose not to return. And, after over ten years of enjoying this location, I will NOT be returning.
author: F. W.

description:
Trying to be productive on a Saturday night is just ridiculous...especially on Polk st.  This place didn't make it any better.  When Michele C and I headed here on a Saturday night in attempts to be productive and knock some homework out so we could spend all day Sunday drinking, acting silly and irresponsible, it was absolutely counteractive.  

Besides the wi-fi not working, the red velvet cake made me sick and had me running to the nasty bathroom.  To top it off some crazy guy sat down next to us and drove me and his date nuts by talking loudly about how awesome he is with a horrendous hyena laugh, when really he was just too blind to see his date could care less. 

We shoulda been at the bar across the street like regular folk.  So much for being productive on Saturday night.  It just doesn't work for me.  I belong at the bar or on the dance floor! 

While the staff were super nice and the space is cool it was frustrating not being able to connect to the Internet at an Internet cafe.  We wasted so much time just trying to get on and stay connected. 

Eh I'll take it as a sign to never try and be productive on a Saturday night again!  If Michele C suggests so, I'll remind her of this night and easily convince her were better off at the bar.
author: Michele O.

description:
Good things about this place are the coffee and the amble amounts of seating.  The service is usually spot on and very friendly.  However, they do get a little rattled when busy.  The wifi has worked every time I've needed, although you do need to buy food or drinks.

Main reason I give it a 2 stars is because of the cleanliness.  It might be because I go there after the lunch crowd, but all the seating is disarrayed and the tables are filthy.  Also, get ready to protect your food from flies (I hope they're not fleas).  If they paid more attention to cleanliness, I would have no objection given Quetzal a 4 stars.
author: JM T.

description:
First of all, I love this place. It is so convenient to everything. They have so many different options for drinks and smoothies and fresh juices. Delicious! Mostly I stop in here for a quick beer to unwind after a long day at work. The staff is completely helpful and friendly. I've never had to wait very long for anything either. 
Their hot tea is delicious. Not pre bagged, it's loose leaf. So tasty! I've only eaten a few things here mostly pastries/bagels but everything was what I expected it to be. I mean you have to try pretty hard to screw up a blueberry muffin. 
I'm here at least twice a week. It's a great place to relax and read a book or surf the web.
author: Victoria V.

description: Yep, it's done-zo for Quetzal.  The food, service, and overall feeling of the place have completely changed.  I stopped by just to see if anything's changed back, but as I sit in the back of the place the thermometer reads 83 degrees, the tables are all covered in a film and haven't been bussed since this morning (by the now fly covered omelet leftovers on the table next to me).  The guy serving was nice, but overall whoever owns this place has completely left what used to be one of the best coffee shops in the city to slide into the abyss.  Maybe having 1 employee will remain profitable, but there are plenty of other great spots to visit.
author: Trifectaus J.

description:
I've only been here for smoothies.
So happy to know there is a smoothie place so close to my place. That takes cards and friendly service (no thank you H2O cafe). 
Everyone here seems to genuinely love their job. There are regulars I see every morning when I walk my dog,  sitting outside talking about politics or the newest book they read whilst sipping their coffee.

I have no problem with this place. And I see signs that they make food late at night. Sounds good to me.
author: Amanda S.

description: A Lower Polk students' dream cafe. The only coffee shop in the area with such a relaxed and generous layout; more windows than wall, spacious seating and tables, a gazillion outlets, healthy plants, and  lighting that's neither too bright or too dim. Quetzal has a lovely openness feeling that you don't often find in San Francisco, yet alone cafes.  The coffee and service is just as impressive AND they stay open until 10pm.
author: Miss K.

description: Bad. Why bad? Try no wifi -- no matter how many times I tried. Add dirty toilets to the mix. Combine that with rather surly staff who were not interested in the customers, over-priced lackluster food items, and a generally unpleasant atmosphere, and 'bad' seems rather a tame epithet. And yet it needn't be so. The location is good, the place has great light, it's roomy and potentially comfortable. But the whole venue needs attention. Badly. I also see some really disturbing comments posted yesterday alleging violence. I won't be back.
author: stuart t.

description:
I only ever stop in for a cup of coffee to go, then I'm out.  But it's a delicious cup.  Fair trade, organic, and it rivals Blue Bottle with its deliciousness.

It's a bit too far a walk from my place to be a regular, but whenever I'm near, I almost always stop in for a quick cup.  So good, and not too expensive at that :)

There's a Peet's & Starbucks a block up on Van Ness, skip them and head to Quetzal.  You'll be all the better for it.
author: Jonathan B.

description: We came here to kill time before a show nearby at the regency ballroom . The cashier was awful and unfriendly and could not answer a simple question snot portion size of the quesadilla that were about to order. She was on her phone the entire time we were there . I asked if I could could use the bathroom... She has to buzz me in . When I got inside I went to use the larger stall but it had crap speared on the toilet seat and 0 toilet paper. When I went to use the other stall the toilet seat looked disgusting but I had to go so I decided to suffer through it and squat . The faulty door did not lock as other users had commented . Since the toilet seat was so disgusting I was mainly focused on squaring and not touching anything when the faulty door swung forward and knocked me hard in the face . Within just a few minutes my noise started turning blue and swollen. Awful place with poor service, standards .. Oh and the quesadilla we ordered.. We left 2/3 of it on the plate because our overall experience was so bad we really couldn't fathom stomaching the food . I never take the time to write these reviews but my busted nose and I needed to express how awful this place was .
author: Schroeder M.

description: Dear Quetzal: I see that you are rating yourself with 5 stars while also being equally shady with Yelp attempting to remove my review. I AM WITHIN THE YELP GUIDLINES. I WITNESSED THIS INCIDENT FIRST HAND! STOP BEING SHADY & SUCH A DESPICABLE BUSINESS & CLEAN UP YOUR EMPLOYEES, NOT YOUR YELP REVIEWS! MY REVIEW STILL STANDS:  My friend & I witnessed a male employee of Quetzal beat a homeless girl down in the street last month, while their douchey patrons stood by & just watched it happen. He delivered a few hard blows to her face & head & then after throwing her down on the ground, kicked her in the ribs, back & head multiple times. The girl didn't even try to defend herself. My friend & I called the police, since nobody else seemed to have the decency to care about the small girl crumpled on the ground. Once they arrived a female employee of Quetzal who resembled a gremlin, tried to justify the public beating claiming it was self defense. Right. She told us to go home & then threatened to beat our asses too. My friend is blatantly 5 months pregnant. Keep it classy Quetzal, you belong in the Tenderloin.
author: Amber S.

description: Artsy cafe that's grossly understaffed for it's size. Food takes an outrageously long time, even when it's dead slow on a Saturday. The quality of the food itself is not bad, but not great either, and is grossly over-priced. The outdoor parklet which should be an asset quickly becomes another negative as  panhandlers are almost guaranteed to come bother you for money, or plop down at the next table over and smoke cigarettes.
author: Jon M.

description:
With the exception of the computers and the high prices, this place reminds me of my days post-college, when I used to frequent Au Coquelet.

I had 40 minutes to kill until work started. I came in, thinking I could eat in with a quick bagel (with lox and cream cheese) and coffee. I bit my tongue at the price, but hoped the food would be worth the price.

If you're eating in, you get a stanchion and someone will be out with your food as you sit in the back seating area. While waiting for my food, I took a brief look at the rows of computers. I was impressed that they had Macs and large screens. I think this may have been the first time I've stepped foot in an internet cafe in the US. 

There were at least 4 other groups/people who were already seated, waiting for their food, too. After a good 25 minutes, they brought all the food out at the same time. If I had been seated earlier, I would have been livid that they didn't bring my food out earlier. Because it did seem like they waited until everyone's food was prepared before they took them out.

So, with only 15 minutes left, I scarfed down my food. The lox was so delicious, as was the coffee. Had I known service would be this bad, I would have made arrangements to come in earlier. This is the type of food that I would linger for, especially since the seating was near lots of windows.

If I'm ever in the area again, I would come back. However, I will make sure I have at least an hour's time.
author: Ruiqiu K.

description: My girlfriend and I managed to kill seven flies during our time here. Won't be coming back.
author: James G.

description:
DRINK:
Coffee


SERVICE:
Order pickup at counter. At least they open pretty late til 2am Sat


ATMOSPHERE:
Kinda cool. Interesting black and white movies played on flat screens and on a big projector in the back wall. Interior kinda reminds me of a Panera Bread or something, except it's dim.. and has a few artworks displayed on the walls. Has wifi, but not free. They give you a log in for 2 hours per purchase. Bathroom requires to be buzzed in. Lots of outlets on the bench seating though. But yeah, not ideal work environment for small bladdz like me.
author: Angela L.

description:
What I remember from my first visit a few months back:

- The guy sitting next to me having an outside voice video conference with someone. Inane subject matter suggested it could have been via chatroulette. So annoying I glared and said something, which was not well received. Teenagers these days.

- Free computers to use, which was awesome when my laptop battery died. Plus it meant moving away from chatroulette guy.

- Something called the sludge cup which combined a clever name with an awesome amount of caffeine.

- An outstanding waffle topped with granola (which might be why it was outstanding)

- An excellent veggie on chiabbata 

And what I definitely remember from my second visit yesterday:

- See No Evil smoothie, jam packed with fruits and antioxidant boosts that was perfect for a warm summer day.

All in all a bit expensive, but worth it, as I was impressed with everything (except chatroulette guy).
author: Jason B.

description:
interesting people watching spot, literally any-kind of.  
cool spot though. They have  a parklett in front which is cool.
author: Lyra S.

description: Interesting seating arrangement. iMac area is pretty neat. 2 hour wifi isn't that hot though I assume you can buy more.  Tuna Melt was fancier than the average coffee shop, served with arugula and daikon slaw.  Hot baristas.  Topped off with a bit of SFPD action outside.  Love the looseleaf tea.  Open "late."  This is the real SF.
author: Eric J.

description:
This is one of my favorite hang out coffee place but lately the operation is really getting terrible. What I mean is the way they conduct the cleaning while the customers are still in the cafe. It's not a pleasant smell when you sit there while the cleaning solution is permeated into your nose.

Other than that, the service at the counter is exceptional. I will rate this a 2 star until they stop mopping or cleaning the place while the customers are drinking their coffee.
author: Dennis P.

description:
Lots of bells and whistles distract from the coffee.

This place is a full-service coffee shop. It's a little too eager to please. Coffee, ice cream novelties, computers, ethernet ports, and beer.

I just want good coffee and a little quiet to collect my thoughts. This is a bit much.
author: M C.

description:
Fairly big cafe with free wi-fi and a bunch of somewhat old iMacs for you to use. They have your usual bunch of lunch items, smoothies, coffees, and hot beverages. They have two flat screen tvs that run music videos and other strange images. In the back they have a really big projector set up. It's weird that they have all these visuals but they seem to run random uninteresting videos.

The lighting is rather poor the evening I came. Sure a lot of people will be on the computers or on their own devices but if you're a book reader you'd be best off going somewhere else.

The bathroom is only available by contacting the cashier who will buzz you in. You won't realize that you need to contact the cashier until you walk all the way up an inclined ramp. Can't they simply put a sign at the start of the ramp? Plus having customers buzz-in to get to the bathrooms makes the place feel like a prison. It's not like the bathrooms are super clean or luxurious either.

My drink was decent. I'm not sure I'd come back unless I needed to use a computer really bad.
author: Michael H.

description:
My GF loves this place, she makes me walk all the way over to Quetzal to bring her back mocha. I don't like doing it, but sometimes a girl just has to suck it up and take one for the team.

Honestly, I don't even like mochas, but I love the ones from Quetzal. They also serve fair-trade coffee and they are also vegetarian friendly. Service is friendly, and they probably offer one of the best spots in the city for WI-FI. The menu looks appetizing, but a bit too expensive for my taste.
author: emily g.

description: A really nice neighborhood coffee shop in the heart of San Francisco.  They make a fine mocha and the apple pie was excellent.  A few tables out front provide a great place to sit down and people watch and chat.
author: Terry F.

description:
My friend really likes coming here after her Spanish class, so after stopping and City Light Bookstore she asked we come here to read.

Our cashier was perfectly friendly, once we started talking to him...no greeting...but he definitely took care of us the rest of the time. I had the Queztal sandwich - meh - and The Larkin shake, which was good but could really go without the banana. In fact, this was the one thing that bugged me about their smoothe offerings, is that all of them included banana. Call me weird, I know, but the one things I love about Blenders and Jamba is that they manage to make thick smoothes without the nasty banana. 

They offered tones of iMacs to surf the web on and there were lots of people play Scrabble and reading. Very quiet overall, a good place for reading and relaxing. 

-1 for the bathrooms. Absolutely disgusting and you have to wait to be buzzed in. Boo
-1 for the floors that needed to be swept, the dirty napkin I got with my silverware all wrapped up in, and the not so fabulous sandwich.
author: Alita M.

description: I liked this place. We ordered a vegetarian pesto pizza and it was ok. fresh ingredients, but kinda oily and thick crust, but I think that's how it's supposed to be. and i ordered a Quetzal smoothie, which was a heavy with the pizza, but yummy. nice, overall. will try something new next time.
author: Afshan K.

description: What can I say; this place is really great. I don't think I can get a better glass of water anywhere else. The glasses are clear and so is the water. But it is not just how transparent the water is but also how good it is. I also enjoy their bathrooms. The first time I asked to be buzzed in, I was a little hesitant because, as you know, all bathrooms are haunted. But once I went in and unzipped my pants I felt emotionally relieved. I laughed for hours. It was great!
author: Roberto B.

description: The owner was pretty nice to me here, he let me stay without ordering anything to check my computer. Which is nice, and of course ultimately you probably will (order something), so I didn't feel bad about it. He said I could stay indefinitely. He seemed like a good man. The prices were high for me, but the attitude was right so I could feel comfortable and respected. I definitely recommend the place.
author: Georgina H.

description:
You know what? I had never been there before and I was desperate one day when I was away from my computer and needed to get a coffee and an email sent off stat!!! I did a quick 'Internet cafe' search based on fellow yelpers and decided that this place seemed worthy. I was very pleasantly surprised. It is bigger than I had expected and the people were very nice. The design is quite upbeat and I do like the bi -level feel to this place. Plus the Internet/computer rates were very reasonable- I only needed to use email but I would definitely come here to lounge about and fritter away the hours doodling or yelping.
ps: I had a big soft  warm choco chip cookie there and it was Dee-lish!!
Rating: Would definitely go back
author: Ms. P S.

description: Free WiFi, outdoor seating, ample indoor seating, fair trade coffee, really good smoked salmon breakfast pizza, omelets, soups, salads and sandwiches. Doesn't hurt that I can practically see them from my window. They have beer and wine which I've yet to try. Don't think there's refills on coffee but not sure. Really convenient neighborhood spot, plus it starts with a Q ;)
author: Faina G.

description: Service after 5pm is below average at best. The cashier couldn't answer basic questions about items on the menu and no one ended up making my sandwich after ordering. Had to ask the manager to check on my order.
author: Corey J.

description: Awesome staff - very friendly, coffee is pretty good. I usually get an iced coffee and peanut butter bagel. Great place to study. Never gets crowded. Sandwiches are delicious as well.
author: Yelperrr M.

description: Worst customer experience ever! When I was here yesterday my sandwich was served on wheat bread. I came back today expecting the same thing, however, it was served on thick focaccia. I politely sent it back, requesting wheat. My server got very frustrated with me and told me they were out of wheat.  "Ok I said. I'd like to pay to order something else."  He threw his hands up at me and stormed off. I consider myself pretty tolerant having worked in the restaurant business myself, but this was pretty inexcusable. If I am paying $10 for a sandwich, I expect a little more in the service department. Maybe I caught someone on an off day, but I won't be back.
author: A J.

description:
I've tried this place four times now, and I really wanted to like it.  Lots of light, internet, coffee, wine and beer, pretty big menu -- what's not to love?

The experience in the mornings is ok.  So-so espresso, pretty good food, and the service was adequate both mornings I went.

Evenings are a different story.  The wait staff I encountered were rude both times; although there are signs advertising "open late night", they closed the kitchen at 9 the first time I went and the whole thing closed at 10.  "We're open late on weekends," they said.  Ok, noted.

Plus, I had arrived at 7:45, so in order to get my last 15 minutes of internet from 9:45 to 10:00, I had to buy something else, which I then had to chug before they closed.  I get why they don't let you sit on your computer forever without buying anything, but it doesn't always work as intended -- or maybe in their view, it does.

I tried again on a weekend evening, and I asked what time they closed.  "10:00" was the answer.  Really?  Maybe they should take down the sign saying open late night.  

I didn't say anything though, went ahead and ordered, and when I tried to pay, they told me they don't take a credit card after 7 p.m.  

Oh sweet Jesus.  Seriously?  So I should go to an ATM and pay $5 in fees for the privilege of having a beer there?  No, no, no and no.  I canceled the order and left.  

This is a good example of how small business owners can send their places downhill by making a few bad rules and hiring a few bad staff people.  

I would give this place a pass if I were you.
author: R -.

description: Whenever I go into the city to take my daughter on an outing, we go here. We've met my parents a couple of times. I love the fact that I can charge my iPhone while I'm there. When I'm out and about all day in the city, listening to my iPod or Pandora on my iPhone, the battery definitely dwindles. I also like the atmosphere in the place. I grew up in the city, and I will always feel happy in a place like that.
author: Atlanta K.

description:
I used to come here back in the day (read:  last fall), and it was pretty chill.  While the music wasn't rad (lazy ambient electronicamy thing), the hot drinks were cheap, and you could chill out and do work in the back for a few hours.  Plus, they were open late.  I then moved to the Mission, haven't been here since until tonight.

The drinks are still cheap, but now you just can't just do the latter anymore.  They've instigated a really stupid "two-hours-per-purchase" policy for WiFi.  Now don't get me wrong, leechers are a big issue at any cafe with WiFi.  But cafes can handle this A LOT  better than a hotel-style wifi system:  Throttling P2P traffic (not actually hard if you understand basic router mechanics), daily password change that requires purchase (which they were doing for the most part anyway, except during the World Series).  This is like the whole Clipper transfer problem:  Such rigidity is not cool.  We freelancers who can only really work in coffee shops and cafes would rather follow our unwritten laws to maintain a degree of modicum than be told what our limits are.

I almost feel like that, since they've installed the draft beer back in November, they've started catering to the urban yuppie scum bar crowd that takes over Polk Street on weekend nights (the same crowd that got rubbed out of SoMa and the Marina by the irresponsible suburban shit that comes in every weekend and wrecks the City).  And if that's your game, just get rid of the cafe in your name and change it to bar.  At least you'd be honest.
author: Sean B.

description: Incredibly dissatisfied by the internet service here, it's spotty and works slowly...
author: Tyrone T.

description:
I never fret when I lose internet connection at my apartment: it's just another great opportunity to go grab a mocha at Quetzal. I wouldn't call their staff "rude" at all: they're polite and they answer all my questions. Do you want good coffee from your barista or a hug? They're busy, yeah, but just tell them you need more time to think, if you're not ready. The cappuccino is good and potent, the chai is sweet and boxed, lackluster. They do the mocha best, especially if you sit in - it's kind of gritty and dark, packs a whollop. I made the mistake of having two, one day, and went through the roof, hands shaking, talking in tongues. The sludge cup is also fantastic - basically a red eye (cup of drip with a shot of espresso. One large coffee is plenty, especially if you tack on another shot, which I usually do.

That, and their daily internet passwords are funny and sometimes oddly relevant to the day's news event.
author: Michelle G.

description: Their coffee is one of the best in town. They have my favorite beer on tap also. The staff are very friendly and nice. I enjoy it every time!
author: Sina T.

description:
This is one of my favorite coffee shops in this area of SF.  They have a great selection of coffees, a small selection of beer and wine, decadent pastries, and good sandwiches.  Other pros include free wi-fi, a TON of seating and tables, good service, and great hours.  I spent a good 3 hours here enjoying the sunlight, catching up on my reading, and people watching.  I enjoyed every single minute of it.  

The only weird thing was that you need to get buzzed in to use their bathrooms, and the walk there is long because their ramp to the bathroom winds around.  So from the time you tell the cashier to buzz you in to the time you get to the bathroom door, the cashier might have already hit the buzzer and you might not have made it to the door, which means you have to go back down the ramp to tell the cashier again and run to the door again, hoping to make the buzz!  (Written from experience!)

Either way, a definite must go!
author: Tram T.

description:
I had one of their ice cream drink but the drink and pastries list is pretty long. 
The service is good and it's a clean location.
There are outlets to charge your laptop everywhere and Internet is FREE.
author: Christian P.

description:
Hazelnut hot chocolate.

I think flavored hot chocolate is my new thing after Cocola (Stonestown Mall) introduced me to their Banana hot chocolate...mmm!

Quetzal is a cool, chilled place for yummy treats!

Hidden treasures in the TL is always cool!
author: Jay C.

description: I decided to try this cafe out for a lunch and work spot - I was extremely disappointed on all counts. The wifi took several tries to find the network and authenticate using a password an employee printed for me. After connecting, it was terribly unstable, it would disconnect after a few minutes and require me to turn off my network and then turn it back on - over and over again, impossible to get any work done. The food wasn't terrible over-all, but they did serve pretty stale bread with a salad and didn't seem to have clean mugs and utensils. There were also small flies that were a lot more into my food than I was. When I tried to get help with the wifi from the manager (or owner?), he was extremely unhelpful - he seemed annoyed that I was asking and kept saying the wifi was working for him. I really don't understand why this cafe is called an "internet cafe" and how it has good reviews. Will definitely not be returning.
author: Mandy Z.

description: I like the food. Some great healthy salads (veggie tofu is great!), the blt is awesome if you are in the mood for a sandwich ...a unique take on the blt...yum...the atmosphere of Quetzal is cool...Great cafe to bring your laptop and do some work or homework....The place is great overall but when ordering for a pick up order make sure to check and make sure they made your dish correctly...There were a few incidences where the salad was not made the same each time, they forgot avacado, didn't grill the bread etc. Rare but it is worth it to just double check. Customer service is great so I give this four stars.
author: S.E. J.

description:
The first time I came here was probably a year ago. This is a dicey neighborhood by day, so imagine what happens at night. Polk Street, while safe if you're north of California, becomes progessively seedier as you wade south of the California Street sign...so be careful.

Warnings aside, this place has good coffee and plenty of natural light. One thing I love is that there are power strips attached to the chairs against the walls. Brilliant idea for people who need to charge their laptop. And phone. And headset. And second phone. And camcorder. You think I'm joking but you could power a village in Asia with the plugs here.

The tables are a bit crowded here, but that was my only complaint. Never tried the internet here or the computers, but rumor has it that the wifi is free. Sounds good to me!
author: Aaron F.

description:
I "discovered" (meaning I walked past it last night and noticed it for the first time) this place last night on my way to my new found obsession--pho at Pho Vietnam. 

The good:
++ The décor = industrial meets vibrant latin influence. Tons of potted plants. Natural light. Immaculate, yet warm. 
++ Pretty huge menu--drinks and foods. 
++ The place is big enough for you to feel comfortable sitting here for hours w/ one drink. It's seriously feels like a restaurant. 
++ FREE and FAST WI-FI! They also have a row of iMacs for public use as well--FANCY!
++ LOTS of power outlets! Hooray!
++ Friendly staff

The bad:
-- Pretty pricey--a pot of tea cost me ~$5-6. Food = sandwiches, brekkie foods, and salads will run you ~$7-10 . Smoothies and shakes ~$5.
-- The bathrooms--they have to buzz you in (no bueno for someone like me, who pees a lot in general).

Mami like!
author: Kristine W.

description:
Ah Quetzal.

I would not describe myself as a coffee person and I am pretty utilitarian when it comes to drinking it. It has caffeine, it's warm, and it gets the job done. However, Quetzal's coffee is an exception, it's more than just another hit of caffeine and is actually quite nice.

The service is pretty much efficient and to the point, although every now and then I get to have some fun banter with clever coffee girl that keeps me sharp in the morning. It's a good thing. 

They have a frequent buyers club and for every $12 you spend, you get a coupon which reads:

SEXY SEXY SEXY SEXY $1 OFF COUPON SEXY SEXY SEXY SEXY

Which needless to say, is pretty good. 

The buyer club comes with a discount as well, I think its something like 15% off. So my large coffee comes to $2.14 instead of $2.37. That's almost a whole quarter! But, over the thousand coffees some people order a year, that can reach about $250.

I have yet to try the food, but it always looks decent. They also serve beer, have wi-fi, and won't bother you if you stay there for hours, which makes this a good place.
author: David H.

description:
This place seems like it has a good vibe, but I was just getting some things to go and I felt that the service was just so iffy. I was ready to order and the guy kept skipping over me and letting others interrupt us. The cashier was in a mood that can only be described as bitchy. And if he wants to use the bitchy attitude towards me, go for it. I won't be coming  back.

Even if the chocolate cheesecake made my fat cry in happiness.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Quick friendly service. Delicious coffee. I spent a week in San Francisco and this was my 1st stop of the day every day. Close to my hotel and better than running to Starbucks or Peets around the corner. 
Too bad it took me til the day before I was leaving to discover their "Death Wish" 
Yummy chocolately coffee goodness!!!
author: Sheri K.

description:
My boyfriend and I have been in here fairly late in the evening to get our evening wind-down/warm-up drinks, but I'd never been in during the day until today.

My company's un-air-conditioned office is pretty hard to work in during this little heat wave, so they've told us to seek out cool air in coffee shops around the city. Quetzal was my choice, and I'm loving it.

It's bright, lively and friendly in here - the male barista is quick to take everyone's order and hasn't stopped smiling. And he makes a freaking awesome quetzal latte - I don't know what's in it but I don't really care.

The wifi is free with purchase, and I've been here 3 hours now with no one bugging me to buy anything beyond that first latte. The music is pretty chill and the place is teeming with locals (the aforementioned barista knows all their drinks), as well as a few relaxed tourists, undoubtedly from the Holiday Inn nearby. Overall, it's very relaxed.

I haven't had any of the food, but a couple of British ladies ordered scrambled eggs which looked amazing, bright and fluffy, and smelled delicious.

Wifi strength seems great, plenty of power outlets and wired connections if needed as well.

Love it here! I wish I could work here every day!
author: Jess H.

description:
Sunday breakfast time! I'm such a foodie. It was cold and windy but I still wanted to sit outside and enjoy their "patio" The staff here is too cute! They are all very nice and attentive. 

Coffee ( def needed it)
Egg/Tofu sandwich-the egg was almost like a soft boiled. It was really good and the tofu combined made it even better. Fruit was exceptionally fresh. Pineapples my fav!
author: Lola D.

description:
If you want a good place to read or study and are only getting a coffee this place is perfect. If you want to eat and are complaining about recession prices then there are plenty of food parlors on this street.

The place is clean (although a little dark for night readers) and the staff is always nice (the owner could smile more)

I don't know why other reviewers are complaining. Would you rather study in one of those 24 hr donut spots? Come on this place far superior than many other cafes that I frequent and they have made attempts at staying open beyond 10 PM which is nice.
author: John B.

description:
I think Quetzal smells funny.

And it's not a funny smell that you can't stop smelling. It's a funny smell that you don't want to smell anymore. Maybe it's just me, but I have smelly issues. Not with myself, of course! 

Other than that though, this place is pretty cool. They have computers you can use, even though most of the people who frequent the place probably bring their own computers. The pastries aren't bad. I think I've had something similar to an apple danish. They also have smoothies (YUM!), sodas, and alcohol. The workers are all pretty nice too.

This place is a one stop shop. You can even stock up on your South American cultural clothing if it suits your fancy, although I'm pretty sure all of those garments have been hanging up on the walls for a while....
author: Maureen B.

description: This is the coffee shop around the corner from my work and I visit regularly. I enjoy their many coffee options but rarely eat more than a pastry or a bagel. I tried a breakfast burrito and for 11 dollars was severely disappointed. The eggs looked like egg beaters , had no seasoning and were watery. The burrito was dripping. Despite this snafu, the bagels are good and so are the pastries. Mona , their mainstay barista and basically the assistant manager is always a joy. She Is the reason most people come . Give her a promotion already.
author: bradley z.

description: This is such a cute coffee shop and not over priced (which is a big deal in SFO)! They have quite a selection of teas and a friendly staff. They don't have many pastries but they do prepare food so there are more options. There is quite a bit of seating and there are plugs all over the room to plug in your laptop. The staff is friendly and gives this place a local feel.
author: Mary M.

description:
This place looked like it had a lot of potential. But like the prideful Icarus aiming for the sun, this place got burned by their attempt at greatness, and by burned, i mean crisp like the piece of macaroni that falls into the flame when your are cooking mac and cheese, and you cant pull it out till you're done cause you dont wanna stop cooking midway through to save one stupid macaroni.

Its time again people for A. B.'s top five list; Quetzal edition. 

1. Do you like cookies? Of course you do, who doesnt like cookies? I'll tell you who, Quetzal. Why? I'll keep telling you. Cookies are one of natures most magical treats, and as such they deserve to be kept in good condition for gastronomical pleasure. Quetzal sadly keeps them in a un-airconditioned box on the counter which gets blasted by the sun all day. So when you get that awesome sounding oatmeal choco chip delish mish. What you get is a rock hard rock of rockiness. And it costs you 2.50. Yup 2.50. For a cookie???????? WTF.

2. onto the food in general. this place tries to bring you the exotic hoity toity fair of an upscale "progressive" cafe, and thats all nice and swell, but now when a fucking bagel with cream cheese costs you 3.50, and a salad plate out of a safeway package costs 10 bucks. I mean cmon, if you make this shit from hand, then sure. But dont bend me over for shit you just stick in the microwave and sever on oversized plates. 

3. WIFI, we all know im a stickler for wifi, and thats mostly because the tech is so cheap at this point it should be free anywhere in the city (see Seoul, korea) let alone in a cafe. BUT NO! Quetzal makes you pay for the overdone priviledge of wifi, and not only that, they give you a 2 hour limit. So if your right in the middle of something important online and you hit that 2 hour mark, so sorry my dear fellow, you gotta go buy another 2.50 rock to get another crack at it. 

4. Atmosphere. Nice and bright ill give em that, but chilly as my uncle vanili. maybe they should have spent less on all these fucking imacs and a little more on some insulation. 

5. Flies. They're annoying right? of course they're fucking annoying, their called flies for a reason fool. And Quetzal has tons of these bad ass winged mofos flying around your dome like it was made out of a poop sandwhich ( not good for the self-esteem, ill tell you that much). I dont know whether they have pools of stagnant water in the back attracting these fuckers (health code violation), or whether the snootyness of all these fucking imacs is stinking up this place and attracting these critters, but either way it aint pleasant. 

There you go, my fellow city dwellers. Another installment of A. B.'s top 5 guides of the good and the bad in our mother and protector, old SF.
author: A B.

description: A coffee shop, also serves beer and wine. They have 15 or 16 draft beers. $2.95 during happy hours. There is a park-let outside the store. You can sit outside when it is warm. It is an internet cafe, not only you can use their wifi. They also provided half dozen of Apple computers for customers to use. I came here for breakfast. Food and coffee is OK, not so impressive.
author: Emmy P.

description:
We go here all the time for breakfast. Lots of seating area, very casual and really nice people working there. They also have a set of computers (I've never used them) as well as WiFi. I'm honestly not sure if the WiFi is free or not, but I suspect it is for anyone who is eating/drinking there. You definitely have to pay (by the minute) for the computer usage.

Their menu has lots of omelettes, frittatas, oatmeal, yogurt, bagels and other bakery items for breakfast as well as salads and sandwiches galore for lunch and beyond; great coffee and also some unique and delicious smoothies. Try the "Quetzal Frittata" or the "Turkish Breakfast" - yummy!
author: Maren P.

description:
The idea for the cafe is essentially this: let's cater to both the hippie-earthy crowd and the healthy-foodies by selling baroque smoothies with amazonian powders as well as handmade gifts from underprivileged communities in other continents. 

Here's why it doesn't work: first, the music.  Oh, god, the music.  Where do they dig up this stuff?  Every song consists of a singer moaning vowels, an indigenous instrument or two, and some synthetic string-chords plunked down in Garage Band.  Many artists are played in the course of a day, perhaps, but they all stick to this theme.  I know saying it's Enya-like is a cliche; but all cliches conceal vital truths.  You can't get work done with that shit. 

Secondly, the prices.  This cafe's location is borderline Tender.  Yet the prices are certifiably Nob Hill.  The crowd is neither--a combination of lawyers, silicons and hostel tourists.

Okay, if you're wealthy and new-age, frequent Cafe Gratitude and think "compassionate capitalism" is a real phrase, you'll go apeshit for Quetzal.  And admittedly, their Chai milkshake is the bomb-dizzle.  But as a workplace for an atheist skeptic, Quetzal is less than stellar. 

(And, if you do the math, you'd only have to buy about 5 smoothies before it becomes more cost-effective to just purchase a blender and some raw ingredients.)
author: Guy M.

description: This place was pretty handy for getting some work done.  They don't have their nomad plans anymore, so you're on the hook every two hours for Internet, but it could be worse.  Coffee, beer, pastries, it's pretty nice!
author: Francis U.

description:
Quetzal provides a good space for meeting friends with free wi-fi, lots of seats, a complete booze and food menu and, yes, even coffee. And though that $1.60 bagel just barely hit the spot, Quetzal offered me something more important: a lesson in modern society...

*talking with a friend about Noise Pop when a guy from another table suddenly leans over*

Guy: Say, are you a registered voter in San Francisco?

Me: Yeah... (wrong answer)

Guy: Great, what district are you in?

Me: Uh... (think fast, Keane)... Alameda?

Guy: Oh, okay. 

*pulls out another clipboard* 

Guy: Would you like to sign a-

Me: NO.

*he walks away, but leaves his phone on the table and it starts ringing loudly*

...

*second LOUDER phone rings behind me*

Girl: ...on MySpace... should I message him? No, on MySpace... On MySpace... Sorry... I'm in a cafe.. I'M IN A CAFE... Should I send it to him? ShouldISendItToHim?! HAHAHAHAHAHA! Oh my God... *sigh* Little boys... He's cute. This boy is 19. That's so wrong...

I totally agree.
author: Keane L.

description:
I get on the phone with my buddy from Brazil and he's like, where are you?

I'm like, "Pretty much where you'd expect.  In a coffee shop with hemp sweaters they're selling and a bunch of organic food and free trade coffee and tofu burgers."

"It's what you get when you live in that damn city so full of hippies."

All stereotypes aside, they are a nice outfit that sells generous buckets of coffee that look like cups and well crafted entrees. The prices don't exactly fill me with love for all mankind, but the decor and well-mannered staff more than makes up for it.

Little did they know I spent the entire day in their hippie shop studying finance so I can widen the wealth disparity between myself and everybody else.  

Irony is my religion.
author: Cassio P.

description:
Pros: internet is fast (must purchase something to use it), plenty of chairs and tables for students to study, bathroom is spacious, offer rental computers, electrical plug at virtually every table

Cons: food/drinks/coffee is a little pricy!
author: Princess N.

description:
LINGUISTICS AND LANGUAGE FAMILY HISTORY 201

It's common knowledge that a "quetzal" is a bird with resplendent plumage found in Central America.  Etymologically, it means "large, brilliant feathers" and derives from the Nahuatl language of the Uto-Aztecan language family.  

In the Indo-European lanuguages, however, "quetzal" means "blueberry scone drier than the ass nuggets from a constipated shitter."

And that ends today's lesson.
author: d s.

description:
The coffee is very good, big selection of loose leaf tea that comes in nice iron teapots, good beers and wine, wonderful cakes and deserts, FREE WIFI, lots of electrical outlets and nice and friendly staff. One of my favorite coffee/temporary daytime office in the city.

It can be very packed during lunch hours, but generally quiet and nice place to work during the day. The lunch selection is not too bad either.
author: Nilesh D.

description:
So far they serve the BEST mocha I've ever had. 

Love the pumpkin pie too. 

You can browse the internet cause they have 3 Macs I think or you can bring your laptop and work on your projects quietly while sipping Mochas. Love, Love this place. 
The coffee is a little bit expensive but it's worth it!
author: Miss C.

description:
During finals this was my second home... and they took DAMNED good care of me. I became a frequent buyer member, and almost every day, I got a dollar off what I ordered; a good perk for many days of stressful crunch-time.

The coffee is so good, and the chamomile tea is even better - the best. I never even liked chamomile tea before I tried it here while coming down off WAY too much coffee. 
The muffins are surprisingly good. I always think of muffins as greasy or dry and as a precursor to an unsettled stomach but these are homemade with organic, high quality ingredients. They're not too sweet and they are MOIST, like cake, almost. The muffins were a lovely find. 
The veggie bagel is such a good deal for lunch. It's truly filling. It's around $5 or $6. They give you a plate with avocado, cream cheese, cucumber, sun dried tomatoes, regular tomatoes, olives, onions etc. and your toasted organic bagel so you can build it the way you like; it's genius!

They also get extra bonus points for their free WiFi and for the good grades that I got on my term papers written at Quetzal. Oh , AND their printer has saved my a$$ sooo many times. 

LoveLoveLove
author: Shanna H.

description:
I echo what everyone else said.

Pros: Free WiFi
Friendly Staff (they don't bug you even if you hang out there for several hours)
Good Healthy Food (good portion size)
Supports going green and other good causes (like Viv)

Cons: A bit pricey (perhaps not as bad if you are a frequent club member)
location (being an out of towner, you need to happen to be in that area)

Overall - a solid place to kill some time or to chill w/ some friends
author: Neil S.

description:
Socially conscious internet cafe in seedy neighborhood = Quetzal.

I'm a big fan of this place because: it's huge, has lots of light, offers an array of drinks, snacks and foods, has ample seating, lots of outlets and free internet. Did I just score on the cafe hunt? Sweet.

Can't really complain about the place because it really does offer a very convenient and conduce working environment. It's very clean and for the most part, people's conversations are kept to a low whisper. They also don't have an overly loud or annoying soundtrack playing in the background which is clutch.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
This coffee shop is  the closest place to my apartment to get really good, fair trade organic coffee. I can't recommend any other drinks or food, but they definitely have a big selection of espresso, tea, smoothies and pastries. They also have pretty adequate out-door seating and free wi-fi. 

The staff is so rude, however. I've discovered they seem better later in the day, and are a little worse in the morning. There is a middle-aged man who works here who is very friendly, but everyone else (who is under 30) has a serious attitude. They rush you through your order, and usually seem annoyed by you. They have a points system where you tell them your phone number and once you spend $12 you get a free drink or something. However, every time I'm here I feel so rushed by the staff that I never even mention it, because surely that will irritate them more. I've been here several times for take-out coffee, so this is an impression I've been given many times.

I want to love this place, and I do enjoy the coffee. The cafe itself is cute so you want to like the ambiance, but the employees make it an always awkward experience.
author: Anne A.

description:
Boy have i been missing out....I've lived 1 block away from this place for over a year and didnt try this cafe til a month ago!

When it comes to what i need from a cafe, Quetzal has all the essentials:
--plenty of space and light
--neighborly and unpretentious atmosphere
--good (organic) coffee
--free and fast internet
--lots of power outlets
--good and mellow music
--open late (10pm!!)

Cute tidbits: 
-They have cute passwords of the day that makes you feel in the know.  It disgustingly gloomy outside today, so the password is "sunshine."  sweet irony.
-Regulars are assigned a customer code.  Mention it when you order and get $1 off every $12 you spend

For a person with ADD tendencies, it says a lot that a cafe has the conducive environment to let me get things done.  It's just the right amount of music and company, without the disruption of loud steamers and shouting of orders being ready. 


So grateful I am to have found this place that as soon as got settled into Quetzal today, i hopped on yelp to give it a well deserve 5 stars :).
author: Kendra W.

description:
The ultimate Internet cafe and one of the oldest (10-12 years at least), everything perfectly tuned for serious computing.  Wifi is free, fast and encrypted (they change the password everyday).  Coffee is excellent.  Decor is warm, dark, industrial, modern, Latin, like flowing low hills dominated by a vast wheelchair ramp that snakes past tall banana trees in the multilevel dining room.  Atmospheric music at perfect volume.

All this PLUS beer and wine, vast (for a coffeehouse) menu of sandwiches, fritatas, pizza, hot and cold sandwiches, and smoothies, and a line of nice handmade Bolivian alpaca vests.

It's a Mac shop through and through but they'll still let you in if you have a PC.
author: Gil S.

description:
Came here to upload an important file, and it would get 5 stars if the upload speeds were faster. Speed test on wifi: http://www.speedtest.net/result/823798251.png

Great place to come for computer use. Lots of space, well-lit, open layout. Lots of outlets for laptops, free wifi with purchase (password changes daily), and half a dozen Macs available for a small per minute fee.

Pleasantly surprised by the loose-leaf tea selection. My white tea was just over $2 and was pretty good.
author: Todd I.

description: Beautiful place, UGLY people. After working for about 45 minutes and ordering food and drink twice in that time, the music was cranked to a level we couldn't even shout above. This is an Internet cafe. Three sets of people were working, including my friend and I. She went up to the counter and politely requested the volume be turned down to the previous level, which had been fine. The female worker walked over and turned it down. Immediately a man came out from the kitchen and turned it back up. My friend walked back up and repeated the request; she turned it down again -- when a SECOND man came out, scolded her for doing so and headed for the volume. The female worker pointed to my friend (also a woman) and started to relay, very meekly, the request, and he looked right at my lovely, kind friend and mocked, "Who? Her? Oh yeah, I heard it," and cranked the volume up double the unacceptable level. "You can go outside if you want quiet" he sneered. My friend and I chose to leave, and the two men laughed as we did, while the female worker cringed. Clearly they are used to bossing women around and being crazy rude for fun. We had been nothing but nice, quiet customers with a perfectly reasonable, polite request. It was clear that not only do they not give a damn about their customers; they actively hate them. NEVER GOING AGAIN, which is a shame since my friend lives close by, and we'd work there often otherwise.
author: Melanie H.

description:
I would give Quetzal a better rating, but Robert (or "Bubble," as my coworkers and I used to call him) is always miserable to have to interact with. 

He's moody and snide, and is the kind of person that will say something to try and make you sound stupid, but it won't be grounded in anything. His sense of sarcasm is pretty generic - he's the kind of person who will say "I dunno, can you?" If you ask "Can I get a latte, please?" And he'll be morose the whole time, like he hates hearing people ask for coffees. 

I think their coffee is pretty good, their blended smoothie drinks and desserts are good, and the other people who work there, especially the two owners, are friendly. It's also clean. I haven't tried their food.

But if you walk in and see a pout, a bowl-cut, a spiky belt, and platform shoes, then be prepared - you're about to talk to Bubble, and he doesn't like you!
author: Heidi G.

description:
Add-ons/enhancers for their smoothes:

flax seed oil
spinach 
ice cream
author: Lijia X.

description: What an awesome coffee shop! Extensive menus, great food, friendly staff, lots of space, and awesome fresh squeezed juices! This place made my morning.
author: Iris W.

description: I'm still trying to figure out how they fit my four dollar and fifty-cent 20 oz. smoothie into a 12 oz. cup.  Maybe it has something to do with the 8 oz. of smoothie that was leftover in the blender...
author: Laurence W.

description:
After going to Quetzal for years and years I realized the staff would just never thaw and give me a friendly hello, unless the exceptionally nice owners were there. And for some reason they did away with table service several years ago, which was strange. So... it is what it is. 

The food is great for cafe food but I just wouldn't describe it as homey or cozy, and the plethora of people alone there on their computers make the atmosphere unappealing (to me). But they are an internet cafe, and that's how internet cafes are hmm? 

However, it's a great place to have a little meeting or grab a bite with a friend, or have a coffee date.  The food and coffee are high quality. Their veggie melt sandwich with artichoke hearts is one of my favorite sandwiches in the city, and they serve a nice salad with all their sandwiches. It's pretty expensive, but they uphold their good quality albeit with a somehow very impersonal atmosphere.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
Enough of the petty complaints you whiners. This is probably the most solid, clean and extensive internet cafe you'll be able to find in the city. Full Apple iMac bar for those without their systems. Lots of nooks for tackling work or just being in your own space.

Considering it's in the pocket of Polk in between Bush and Geary, would give it even more stars for having such a full capacity of engaging people -- on a Monday night.

Solid food all around and reasonable prices. Great cafe menu and drink options for all ages. Fair trade products, responsibly sourced coffee. Nice to have a tribute to the Quetzal as well. We've always had a great experience with the staff here, so I am guessing the complaining visitors are as peculiar as their reviews.
author: Tanya P.

description:
3 1/2 Stars

Convenient and semi-nearby, I come here pretty often to read/study/do my laptop thing here.


PROS:

-Their Chicken Cesear Salad is the bomb diggity
-Free Wi-Fi!
-There's a huge selection of drinks. They even have yummy ice cream blends!
-Super nice MACs are available if you need computer access.
-There's lots of seating w/ tons of discreet outlets to hook up your laptop. (Major Plus!)
-Most attentive coffee shop service yet. They bring your drinks/food out & the manager helps you out if you have a question/prob.

CONS:

-A little drafty w/ its high ceilings & industrial-like ramp. The place could be much cozier.
-A bit on the pricier side
-Neglected bathrooms. I understand why they've gotta do the whole bathroom buzz-in thing to keep out the crazies, but it's a major pain in the butt.
