Overall, Quetzal caters to pretty much everything I need to get the job done- a place that will always have seating for me, a nearby outlet, wireless, & a variety of snacks to keep me satisfied. I just wish it were a little more comfortable.

NOTE: Beware that this is not a social meet-up spot. This is more of a "get your shit done here" kinda place.
author: Tiffany M.

description: After a long day of legal terminology and heels, the last thing I want to do is sit in a coffee shop with Indian music blasting so loud it'll make your ears bleed. To make matters worse, the  40 yr. old barista was playing DJ, and kept alternating from one horrible style of music to the next. I was thrilled his next musical selection was some type of hippie/ disco, which I'm sure reminded the guy of his psychedelic tie-dye  and "sticking it to the man" past. With watered down chai's and slow wifi, this place deserves one star, but I'm feeling generous.
author: Gabriella C.

description: Good place for coffee, but not a relaxing spot.  A lot of foot traffic and a lot of people parked at tables with their laptops. Anyway, friendly staff and a good cappuccino.
author: Scot W.

description:
I'm not sure how people "work" from Cafes.
I literally lost my office at the end of February. 
My new one won't be ready until the end of this month.
So except when I go in and carve out some room at Jill K.'s desk so she can have the honor of staring up my nostrils, I work from home.
And as lovely as home is, its kind of dark and uninspiring plus some food is constantly calling me to eat it or some dish to wash it.
It's a demanding kitchen.
So you'd think I could go to an Internet cafe and get things done.
I've tried it and I just don't get it.
How do you get anything done?

Quetzal is the perfect example of this situation.
Discounting the heat, as I went on the hottest day of 2007 to date for a meeting where this place was like the inside of a pizza oven, I don't see how anything gets done.
It appears people are working but that also includes them working in groups, talking loudly and endlessly on their cellphones where they disclose an enormous amounts of corporate and personal secrets.
If you thought Microsoft's plan to take over Yahoo! was big news, you won't believe what I heard at the table next to me while I was fanning myself while the person across the table from me was spewing I don't know what but what I had come to this cafe to meet about.  

Who could pay attention?  There was so much going on and if it wasn't the patrons, it was the vroom vroom of the blender, 2 or 3 going at a time to make the smoothies.  Granted on a hot day everyone was reaching for their healthy smoothies, I did and I appreciated the opportunity to go vegan with my smoothie which I did not or go with a protein, which I did.  The smoothie itself was tasty.
I have to say, I make better smoothies though.  And for a cafe, I mean a professional place that makes smoothie, I was surprised that they have less luck than me at keeping the seeds to a minimum. 

Seeds?  Yes, you see it is far better to have berries than bananas when you are reaching for fruit, less sugar and all but when you mash the berries, oh there goes those little, crunchy, not terribly tasty seeds.  At home the seeds tend to gather at the bottom, here they seemed like they were all throughout the drink.  

The place is terrifically designed that looks like they could trade out for a nice bar or club at night.  The bathroom on the other hand~~~danger Will Robinson!~~~~~it's some elaborate "barista will buzz you in" set up but apparently the barista buzzed someone in who vomited at some point in the day because though there was no evidence of it the place just reeked of it.  Smell aside, it resembled a fast food bathroom on Route 5.  No one gets in here much to clean.

Which makes me wonder even more, how could you work here?
author: Sean S.

description:
Gluten-UNfriendly place. The counter person didn't know what gluten entails, so she asked the owner, who had no idea and stated that only ingredients on the menu was in the food.
So I switched the Cheddar with Mozzarella, and the owner asked me about it to explain to him what cheeses were safe etc. After explaining for a bit he didn't really get it and kind of brushed it off and I was starting to get annoyed.
My coffee was alright. 
Of course, my Frittata came with an English Muffin... haha, really?  After already explaining that I was allergic to gluten and couldn't have wheat, rye, or barley products. My friend takes the english muffin back and the manager just laughs. I mean yea, they made a mistake and could have apologized, but I don't understand what was so funny.
Besides my frittata had traces of Mozzarella, and of course a little later I had allergic reactions and my lip swell up, it wasn't pretty. It definitely is close to my friend's place, but next time I will just order a boiled egg, to definitely be safe, as they don't take orders very well here. They couldn't do anything wrong, or contaminate my food with sprinkles of gluten.
author: Dat P.

description:
I use to be customer #7, lived exactly one block away, my apartment number was 7....and then I moved with my stupid ex- boyfriend of 7+ years.  Granted we only moved a couple of blocks away, but for one reason or other we just couldn't get our asses for our morning cup of joe.  Actually  I could get me ass there, but his was rather fat and lazy so...you get the point.

Anywho, Quetzal's has the best coffee around.  Now I don't go in there as often as I used to, but every time I do I realize the only thing I miss in the past 7 years is there coffee.  Next time I go in I'm buying a bag to bring home.  Oh yeah and they have internet access :)
author: Amanda P.

description: Update: the 2 hour time limit on wifi can be annoying and is a questionable strategy overall...most cafes don't do this.
author: Karl P.

description: Great coffee, and their breakfast foods are delicious if a little pricey.  The ambiance has shifted to more of a bar or club feel.  It's a little cramped.
author: Nicolas B.

description: I found this place after parking in the Polk & Bush garage.  The coffee is great.  I had the caramel macchiato.  I ordered a blueberry bagel with cream cheese and wasn't terribly impressed. It was pretty mediocre compared to Noah's bagels. Next time, I'll order one of their delicious looking pastries.
author: Amanda C.

description: One of the best ginger cookies I've tried and definitely the best rice tea!
author: Ira E.

description:
Their coffee (and when I say coffee I mean froo froo espresso beverages) is some of the best in the city  (its so weird to me how many coffee shops in SF make such awful lattes).

They have this sandwich called the Quetzal club which is $10.  Now, I've barely gotten used to a sandwich costing $7 but somehow I come here with my last grubby little $10 bill and get that sandwich and am HAPPY.

Their smoothies actually taste like fruit which puts them one up on Jamba Juice.

Do not be afraid of this place with its odd architecture, elaborate bathroom rituals and hulking computer section.  Just eat and/or drink.    Its good.  I promise.
author: Flemm F.

description:
Things I love about Quetzal:  

1) Fantastical caramel lattes with just the right amount of foam on top

2) Located around the corner from my ridiculously unpredictable job which has driven me to consume ungodly amounts of caffeine

3) Joining their frequent buyer club means getting a $1 coupon everytime you spend some undetermined sum.  It's actually not undetermined.  I'm pretty sure its determined.  I just don't know it.  I do know it makes me really happy when the guy ringing me up says, "Oh!  And you've got a coupon today!"  Yay for me!  But that's not even the best part.  The best part is that the coupon says "thank you thank you" along the top and "sexy sexy sexy" along the bottom.  I mean, who doesn't want to be told they're sexy?  And not just once, but three times!  

Things I hate about Quetzal:

1) Serves crazy expensive food that I can't afford because I work with homeless teenagers and which leads me to 

2) The fact that I have to walk by 10 of my clients hanging out on the corner smoking a joint on my way to get my own fix

3) You have to be buzzed into the bathroom like they're afraid that you could be a cracked out junkie looking for a quiet place to take a hit.  Which is probably exactly what happened in order for them to take such precautions.  And it was probably one of my clients.  Sigh.
author: Karen Y.

description:
I'd only ever gone in this place for coffee.  Mocha to be exact.  YUM.

Their mocha is the best I've ever tasted in the city.  My BF and I used to go to Brain Wash, Peet's, even Starbucks on the way to work for coffee, but finally tried Quetzal and haven't changed since.  Their coffee, mochas, lattes are made to absolute perfection, plus they're nice and HOT...just the way I like it.

Aside from the amazing coffee, my mom was visiting awhile back.  She had couple hours before she had to leave for her flight.  We went to Quetzal for some coffees.  I was hungry all of a sudden.  And I've had their croissants and muffins before (very good) but I needed something more substantial.  I read over the menu and decided the fruit and pancakes with walnuts sounded yummy.

Wow I was soooo impressed when they brought it to our table.  Tons of gorgeous delicious fruit piled on top of soft pancakes sprinkled with walnuts and an optional very very light syrup to use.  It was so good.  

I'm dreaming about it now... *drool*

Anyway, the owner is the nicest man you'll ever meet.  They actually care about their service and know almost all their customers by name if not by their "usual" drink order.

Simply the best.
author: Mary R.

description:
Good music, super easy internet access, lots of room to spread out, and if you are not so lucky, the occasional guy asking you if he has B.O even though he does not - which makes for really awkward conversation opener.

Slightly great smoothies too!

Overall, this place will get me by while I await for ATT to install interwebs in my apartment. Bring it on.
author: Julie H.

description: This is too bad. I buy a gift card for 30bucks from it and after just couple of times they always said can not work any more .now I have 20$ in the card and can not get them back. Everytime they said next time or their boss is not here , etc bs stuff. Can someone help me how to get my money back?
author: Yong Z.

description:
I loved the Greek breakfast sandwich: very tasty and using good/safe produce (organic eggs). 

They also sell organic coffees.

Nice spot and nice people too.
author: Laurent C.

description:
Great place to work, save for the occasional city noises (bear in mind that firetrucks going by sound a lot louder in the summer, when they open the windows to the sidewalk seating!).  Bring a pair of headphones and you're set.

Wifi is free with a purchase, and you won't get that "I just paid $3.75 for a stale cookie when all I really wanted was the wifi" feeling.  Their sandwiches are excellent and they make neat-o frozen fruit "smoothie" type drinks.

The place has power running throughout, on built-in power strips by all of the tables, so you won't be forced to stalk 'certain' tables with AC outlets nearby. Every seat has several outlets close by, so you can charge your laptop, phone, etc. at the same time- a nice touch!

Most folks seemed to be using the wifi, but there were a couple of routers stocked with RJ45 cables  in sight for those without wireless capability.  There were also about a dozen imacs lined up for those without a computer.  You can print too- very convenient for printing out those last minute boarding passes!

The chairs could be a little more comfortable, but I guess that's nit-picking a bit.  Overall it was an excellent experience.  I'll be back!
author: Greg G.

description:
Feeling sluggish?  Large au Lait and a Whole Wheat Sesame Bagel with Veggie Cream Cheese Spread.

Feeling indulgent?  Mocha and an Apricot Scone.

Feeling deficient?  Fear No Evil Smoothie (OJ, Banana, Blueberry, Strawberry, Wheatgrass, Spirulina, Echinacea, Siberian Ginseng, Quetzal's Boost).

No matter how I wake up feeling, Quetzal has what I need to get me off to a good start in the morning, and sometimes for a pick-me-up in the afternoon.  What makes it special for me is that Wayne is one of the nicest guys in this city and he always remembers my name and usual order in a way that makes me think that I have temporarily landed in Lake Wobegon.  Gosh, I like that feeling.  

All coffee is Organic Free Trade, roasted on the premises, so you can feel good about that, too.  

Quetzal offers salads and sandwiches for lunch, which are good but on the expensive side, so I usually make this my regular stop for breakfast instead.

In my fantasy life, I go to Quetzal, pick out a a sunny spot, surf the net and write reviews all day.  It's a place to hang out and take things slowly - however, they handle the morning crowds with ease.  Which ever speed your day is set on, a visit to Quetzal is a fine way to get going.
author: Liz S.

description: I've been coming for a while so far good service. The staff were great.  5 star service. But lately it's gone down hill.  The last time I was there I was next in line and the people behind me were waited on before me. The girl at the register didn't even look at me. She was busy with the register for about 5 minutes. So, that said 1 star.
author: Seth T.

description:
Where else in the area can you be guaranteed a cafe with a nice big table, some cool music for you, wiFi, and if you stay til lunch, a gourmet sandwich?  The tables are large enough for all your books, or for
playing board games (unlike the small circular tables at other cafes).
The music is also pretty cool, although often they play the same thing over and over again.  Usually it's OK, except one time when they were playing some Yanni-style music over and over and I nearly walked out.
The chicken breast sandwich is scrumptious, served on pita bread, real cloth napkins, heavy silverware, and a healthy salad. $10 is a decent price for that.  There are some problems--for example, to use the bathroom you have to grab the attention of a counterperson. 90% of the time this works, the other 10% it's a drag, because you have to walk back down the ramp to the front,etc. But at least this keeps the bums out of the bathrooms, which is pretty clean (but not up to my gf standards).
One night, this horrendous grinding noise started about 6pm. It was their "roaster" and it was very disruptive. It went on and on, and after 40 min we asked how long it was going to take, and they said a couple more hours.  ?? We left. Sometimes the place is too hot or too cold, too dim or too bright, and the wait staff is either spot-on, or dim bulbs.
But you can't beat the spacious atmosphere, elbow room, decent coffee and usually cool music.
author: Greg M.

description:
This is a really nice coffee shop.  I just got a standard coffee when I went there, and it was good.  It's very clean and airy inside.  The coffee is fair trade and stuff too,   ...man.*

I would go there more often, but Cup-a-Joe is closer to my apartment AND serves beer!

*I could go on and on about this, but "fair-trade" is not really a good idea economically.  But you hippies wouldn't listen to me anyway.
author: Rocco B.

description:
The only reason that I come here is because it's on my way and it has a printer. I don't know what the problem is but one of the Baristas consistently ignores me, generally condescends to me and always makes me feel unwelcome. The others are fine. I was in the front of the line and I tried to order and she asks for the order of the person behind me.

The Internet seems to have a strict filter on, I can understand not wanting users to be I don't know, watching porn or something, but it filtered out some websites that really weren't necessary.
author: K J.

description:
love to come here and spend a day to do work or have serious concentration.

Done it twice thus far but warning that it DOES get busy quickly. and fairly hot if you sit near the windows on a nice day.

They've got a nice arrange of drinks/foods (pretty good price, food's a little more expensive for what it is)

Free internet as long as you buy something, password changes daily...just ask one of the workers/cashiers
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description: Great place to grab a coffee or beer before a concert at the Regency.  Coffee's good, beer's cheap, free wifi with purchase.  Bathroom is annoying to get to and have opened for you.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Oh hello new coffee shop friend. You are my new home. Upon initial inspection it was a bit mid-nineties New Age-y for my taste with a highly structured chair arrangement, world music (a bit fuzzy, but if I remember right, yes),  Latin American native clothes for sale, and  one curt employee who seems to always be there. (Heidi G. below this post used the right word, "snide")
   I then had their tea, and oh it is amazing. I can drink it all day. Earl Grey by the way. In the pot.  I never pay more than five bucks with enough bagels and tea to make great progress with whatever my shenanigans are for the moment. Also, stable internet, and good people. And that guy, upon further goings to,  I think he's just like that. Really good art in the back.
author: Christian M.

description: Been going here for over a decade.  Great quirky place.  I only wish they had better selection of tea.
author: Kanai K.

description:
Queztal is hands-down the best place to get work done on your laptop while being comfortable. It has the best layout for computer work: large tables and counters, power outlets galore and even wired access in some spots!

The coffee is good, the atmosphere is good, the music is not too loud, the staff is friendly, they have beer, and the beer is cheap, they have some food.

Only downsides: To far from mass transit and no real lunch food selections, ust baked goods.
author: Steven P.

description:
I love that I have this place to go to everyday on  my lunch break. The coffee,  smoothies, food, and staff are great! I have been going here nearly everyday Monday through Friday for the past 3 years. I am always welcomed by name, mainly by the owner Wayne and Gaspar. 
They are very accommodating, if there aren't enough table outside to sit and eat your food, before you can ask they are right beyond you with a table and chairs, amazing service. 
They have Mac's available to use with printing behind the counter safe to be picked up when you are done. The ambiance if very nice with music that reminds me of my traveling days. 
Great place, great coffee!
author: Jenny M.

description:
Here is my bad first experience at this place.
I always make it a point to write a review if I have an unusually bad experience at a place.

I just moved to the lower nob hill area and I walk to work near civic center everyday.
I always get coffee at a place close to my work [Emily's near Polk and Turk] and I always get a small coffee in a medium cup since I need a bit more cream than others and I don't like to keep dumping
coffee in the garbage to make space for cream.

Since this place is on my way and never been here, decided to get coffee from here one day.
I asked the guy taking orders for a small coffee in a medium cup. He gave me just that.
Then when I was paying, the dark, curly-haired woman at the cashier told me the price for a medium coffee. I told her I am only getting a small in a medium cup thinking that she just saw my cup and
charging me medium. She tells me that she is going to charge me for a medium because I am going to use more cream. WOW! that was kind of shocking. Never heard of such thing anywhere. It's like
charging you for large fries when you get a small one because you use more ketchup than the other person. Looks like she would rather have me waste the coffee by dumping it and make space for the cream.

Obviously I did not like the way she treated me, so told her I don't want the coffee, walked to the new coffee shop that opened at Geary and Polk.
Asked him for medium in a large cup. He gave me that and said he'll only charge me for a small cup since their cup size is smaller than other places. I gave him an extra tip and walked away as a happy customer.

This place definitely needs to hire some people with business skills, especially in this economy.
author: luvmunky B.

description:
This is probably one of the best, most reliable internet cafes I've been to.

Encrypted, fast wifi, good eats and delicious coffee and they're open until 10!  I have started frequenting this place so much I think the staff might recognize me now and that always makes me feel like a big dork.

One less star because their food is mad pricey, yo!  I mean, I get it...it's organic and quality and that's cool but like, sometimes it'd be nice to go in there and not end up spending $15 on a sandwich and a drink.

Still, it's worth it to me because the perks outweigh the cons.

Also, I just love getting lost in thought while I gaze at those little woven ponchos along the wall.
author: Carla C.

description: I don't end up in here often enough but I do have to say that the Quetzal Mocha (I think it's off the menu at this point) was my favourite of them all. It was definitely something I'd treat myself to once in a while but it was good. Kind of sugary but not overly so. Service is prompt and it's a great place to run into if you're somehow without the Internet (as I was for a bit) but aside from that, there wasn't much that differentiates it from a Starbucks.
author: Shauna S.

description:
My husband and I have been to Quetzal many times for breakfast, on mornings where we wanted to spend time with our laptops. We were big fans at first, also the loyalty program sounded really good, until I started asking for the receipt and saw that they often tried to over charge us. So the 1 USD payback that you get is only just to make you feel good, as you pay more when they charge you the wrong price. 
At first, they were really friendly too, that was early 2007, but then a new guy started there and he has this slight arrogance about him that i don't like. 
The food is decent and the wifi is free but since it's not the coziest place in the world and the servers got less friendly and more arrogant, we hardly come here any more.
I have to mention their fruit smoothies though, which are great. You can get them to go, so no worries ;)
author: Alexandra D.

description: I tried to give this place a chance, but each time I have been there it's been an exercise of irritation.  The food is pretty good but it takes FOREVER to get your food. 90% of the people in this cafe are there for pay-by-the-minute computers. So I have no idea why it takes so long to get fed. Oh, wait, there's only like 2 people working there. Annoying. I won't be going there again, at least not for food.
author: Jeff R.

description: over priced, poorly run and OSHA violations all over the place. employees, please wash your hands when coming in from a cigarette break and then proceeding to prepare customer food/beverages in front of them.
author: Claire M.

description: Reasonably priced, great staff/service and good food and tea.
author: Jimmy M.

description: this is my favorite coffee shop in SF. I always get to meet cool people here and the employees are very nice. Although everything is a little bit expensive than other cafes, I like the taste and strength of their organic coffee. The service can be slow at times but 4 stars for the cute handsome employee with really striking eyes... ;-p
author: Kayla G.

description:
Mmmmmm iced coffee.  Mmmmmm FREE iced coffee courtesy of my new little brother/best unemployed buddy Adam M.  Mmmmmm flirty counter staff.
OUCH!  Those are some expensive eats.  I think I'll pass there and stick with the coffee.  The coffee happens to be free trade which will make some of you feel good and others of you (like me) only care in so much that it also tastes good.  And "no" you don't get a tax write off.  I asked.
author: Jill D.

description:
Something is amiss in coffeeland... it goes by the name of Quetzal. I drink here somewhat regularly, but there is a undertone here that I can't quite get my hands around. Is it the fact that the place resides in the belly of a new just add water insta-building? Is it the odd footprint of the joint? Is it the need to be buzzed into the bathroom gig? It's probably just the location, it's age, and layout that steals a little from the heart and soul cause it's not Cuppa Joe, but it serves a better espresso.

Pluses (is that a word?): good espresso drinks, friendly/cool/laid-back staff, eclectic crowd, free wireless, fairly clean, Apple loyalty, hours. Minuses: strange vibe that lives in the walls, food prices.
author: Rob S.

description:
Get there early on the weekends, cuz it fills up quickly after 10am.

Great speciality coffees and breakfast selections, even for a vegan...like my kid.

Relaxing atmosphere.  I never feel rushed.
author: Maggie K.

description:
Possibly the best bbq chicken sandwich in SF!  A little pricey, though it does include a good, fresh and organic side salad. 
Staff is always very friendly and their "frequent flyer" discount program shows that they aim to please.
author: KT F.

description: Good coffee. Somebody once stared at me through the window for a long, long time, which was weird. They don't make you feel like you have to leave and the food is actually pretty good. I sort of hate that you have to be buzzed into the bathrooms and the place isn't quite cozy, but I would go back.
author: Andrew K.

description: Some people may think I'm a wee bit dull, I suppose my cafe au lait is up there with boring compared to the excitement of Quetzal's menu. The menu seemed stacked with interesting coffee drinks and yummy smoothies just as the walls are stacked with interesting pieces of international items for sale. The ambiance is equal parts cafe, wifi office for those office-less and yard sale all rolled into one. I, for one, prefer the first and that is why I check out Quetzals.
author: Vee B.

description: Man it is relaxing in there!!! Yummy chocolate cake, also love the  art, hehehehe
author: Mia D.

description:
Considering this is on the lower end of Polk with lots of filth in the area, it is amazingly a  good environment. It does not get the creeps and freaks that It's a Grind gets, however, it has one every now and them....afterall I am there.
I will say he choice of Asian eye candy is very good, simply because it seems a lot of Japanese live nearby and go in there. They are the hottest of the hot when it comes to Asians, the Japanese certainly put all other Asians to shame....looks, dress, intelligence, man they are so hot.
Now Quetzal the advantage is the bathroom is locked and in the back upstairs so you have to get buzzed in.  That eliminates the homeless from showering and bathing in there as well as leaving gifts on the floor for next patron to happily find.
The selection of food and drinks is plentiful, although I have never ate there just drink my tea.
Also they have Apple computers for those to use for a small fee. It is not a bad vibe at all, the kid behind the counter, his name is I think Robert, can come across with tude but does not mean anything by it, just his nature. I will give this place a solid thumbs up, service, ambiance, and of course eye candy
author: Kenn P.

description:
We were coming from the bar (good thing they sell beer)

I had a salmon and brie sandwich that was fantastic!
author: Danielle V.

description: I was just here w/ a friend for coffee & dessert today, after having had Thai food for lunch...It's an awesome place to hang out!! I'd highly recommend this place!
author: Annette L.

description:
This is my new favorite coffee shop. From the exterior, the shop may appear  small, but I was plesantly surprised to discover the amount of room and space inside. The servers are always friendly and helpful. I never had a problem looking for seating and the background music is not loud or distracting. It is perfect for a coffee date or even to study. 

During the day, the sunlight floods through the window so it gives it a warm feeling. Cakes, bagels, coffee, & ice tea are all delicious. I had one of their salads and it was huge, but delicious. It's the best when you eat something light and yet it is so filling.The best part is they offer free wi-fi and there are plenty of electric sockets for the wi-fi junkies. 

Overall, I love this place so much better than The Grove which is more for hanging out and people watching, but too noisy for me. One final note, the hours of operation are excellent and you never get distracted except for occasional study sessions where people sitting next to you are mediating. Personally, I find that interesting and highly entertaining.
author: Sophie C.

description:
This is my current favorite coffee shop in the city. Friendly staff, lots of seating, though it can get pretty full, and awesome weird smoothies. I usually  splurge for a muffin or pie, sometime I hope to come by and try their lunch and breakfast.

On a good day, you can also sit outside. There are bike racks visible from the window, so you can keep an eye on your ride if you decided to bike and not park in the huge parking garage above the coffee shop.

The encrypted wifi works pretty well, but I've hit some dead spots and had to move around until I could find signal. Beware of the encryption key they give you: make sure they write it down. I was told the day's word was "albatross" , but they had spelled it as "albatrose" in the wifi router. That was a head scratcher for a few minutes!
author: Mark B.

description:
For a few short weeks Quetzal was my local cafe and I made enough use of it to sign up for the "frequent buyer" thing, but not long enough to reap it's rewards.  You sign up with your phone number and are given a four digit code (the end of your telly #) to tell the cashier whenever you buy a drink, and somewhere - magically - a team of Quetzal elves calculates your running total and you're awarded a free drink.  I don't know if you get  a coupon in the mail or if you're surprised with a "This one's on the house, ma'am."  Sadly, I didn't live in the Tenderloin long enough to find out...

That said, Quetzal is a lovely place to get some work done.  As said before, they have free wifi (be sure to ask the barista for the password, which changes regularly - though not daily, as they insist.)  There are lots of tables and outlets and most customers have a laptop in tow.  I never drank the coffee, but the chai was good and their smoothies are pretty rocking.  They also serve wine & beer.

The sandwiches and salads are good but expensive for their size - most near $10.  The sandwiches come with a mixed green salad and house dressing, which is tasty but will stay on your breath for hours - beware!
author: Holly B.

description:
There has been an addition of lots of tables, counters, stools, etc. The end result is less USABLE seating.  It is almost a health hazard finding a seat.  You may have to walk on tables to get to your seat.

REPEAT seating area is a health hazard.

A parklet has been added outside in front.

Lots of different kinds of beers on tap at very good prices.

Bathroom access was a BIG problem, but the bathroom has been unlocked now for several weeks. THANK-YOU BATHROOM GOD.

The pastries when fresh are good.  The cakes and pies dry out once the first slice is taken so the remaining servings are kind of dry.  Often the muffins are dry.

Cookies go fast and are very good.  Not sure about the vegan cookies, some love and so don't love.

Bagels are very good with many different toppings.

Lots of fantastic coffee and non-coffee smoothies. You will have to open your wallet WIDE for the smoothies.
author: DAVID R.

description: Yummy soy chai latte for good studying time.
author: kate w.

description:
Like it quite a bit and it's spacious enough that you can usually be assured a seat.  The coffee is pretty good, especially in the fanciful coffee concoctions that come in big sippy mugs.

I dock it a star mainly because it's in a dicey area of Polk Gulch so the foot traffic can be a bit on the confrontational side.  I've had to dodge a few unsavory characters which is tricky when you are on a low tank of caffeine.

Also the service can be painfully slow when busy - this place is best hit when there is no line queued up.

Also, access to the bathroom is a bit challenging in that you must ask the staff to buzz you in, so must make a mad dash to the door then.
author: Femita J.

description:
Food (Food) : **** (4)
Desserts : *** (3)
Coffee, Coffee-like-drinks : **** (4)
Smoothies : **** (4) (I heart smoothies)
Service : **** (4)
Location : ***** (5)

I don't know how to be more upfront about this, but do not go to their bathroom. I suppose there's a reason they have this li'l clickety system of selectively letting selective people in to the selective bathroom. But if you absolutely have to go, hold you breath, do you business and run out.

"ai"
author: Anand I.

description:
Decent coffee. Friendly-enough staff.  Sometimes, a little over-friendly, if you know what I mean.  But, I love that frequent buyer number thing and that the coupons say, "sexy, sexy, sexy" or maybe it is just my coupons that say that.  Hey-yo!  

Downsides: It's not the hang out and be seen kind of place.  The atmosphere is a bit cold for me for me so I don't like staying there.  Takes forever to get your bagel to go and they never have anything but weird bagel flavors left on the weekends past 10am.  Tried the waffle and it sucked. Bland, chewy, ugh!
author: MakeUp M.

description:
I come to Quetzal a lot.  Why? Well, usually I'll be somewhere around Market & Van Ness when I decide that I'm really hungry.  My next thought is "Hey Polk street is right there! There's lots of places to eat on Polk Street." This is true, but not really true in the Tenderloin/close to Market section of Polk.  So I end up walking all the way up Polk St. until I get to Quetzal, at which point I'm so hungry all of there food tastes amazing.  Now, it might not taste as amazing if you haven't just walked 20+ blocks to get there, but I couldn't tell you.

Usually I enjoy a toasted bagel with cream cheese and raspberry preserves because it's only $2.00 and it's fast and filling.  Their Chai ice cream smoothies are really really good too. 

The staff is super nice and eager to serve, and they might let you use their computers without paying if you're nice.
author: Maia B.

description:
They have some of the biggest, freshest salads in the area. The randy baby sandwich is awesome as well. Kind of expensive until you get the food...then its all good. Their smoothies are pretty cheap, filling and delicious. For their coffee, I really appreciate that they have soy milk out so you dont have to feel like the pretentious dick asking for it. 
ooooooh and their cookies are super yummy and the girl behind the counter is super sweet.
author: Jennifer L.

description: I wandered into this industrial-chic cafe after dropping off my City Car Share jalopy in the adjacent garage. The barista/cashier was super-friendly and made me my non-fat chai latte with a smile on her face. The chai itself was way too sweet for my liking (nobody can beat Peet's), but it was nice to check out someplace different. Tons of space for WiFi users and lingering chatterers. I fell under neither category, so drank my tea and split. Interesting joint.
author: Gregor G.

description:
(The review begins with the requisite pointless bit of Yelp review dialogue that shows how far I have to go as a humorist)
 
  Scene:  Quetzal Coffee Shop.

  Man at the Table Next to Me:  Boy, I sure like drinking coffee!

  Eric:  Could you keep it down, guy?

  Man at the Table Next to Me:  Excuse me, I have to answer my ringing cellular phone and talk loudly about personal things.  Rest assured, my speech will be filled with profanities, as I am completely unaware of the elderly women sitting at the table next to mine who probably aren't too jazzed about starting their Sunday mornings hearing a stream of obscenities.

  Eric (to audience):  That's okay, I was going to leave anyway.  (exit stage left)
---------

  While I am bugged by the constant din of people in public on their damn phones who seem completely oblivious to humanity(because I am secretly an old man), I can't say much of anything negative about Quetzal's, which expertly serves up slightly more than the average coffee shop (or cafe, whichever sounds more pretentious).

  The main draw for me here is the atmosphere, which is conducive to an atmosphere slightly slower than the average coffee shop bustle.  They offer internet at several computers, which seems  generous. 

  On the negative side, they get my order wrong sometimes.  And I don't even order the silly complex stuff, just normal coffee or a bagel.  But I don't fault them, I'd do a much worse job.

  This is a good place to unwind or wait for the mental blocks to dissipate.
author: Eric P.

description: Hadn't been there for years but was pleasantly surprised by how well it's kept. Great for a bite and a caffeine selections. Nice art and great environment in general. Included wifi is fast. You can work done if you don't get distracted by awesome people-watching in large front windows to a flavorful Street.
author: Julia S.

description: This place is pretty great because a) it's organic coffee b) it's huge c) the menu has a wide array of snacks and sweets and d) it's open pretty late.
author: Catherine C.

description: A reasonably quiet,  well-light place to snarf wifi, over-caffeinate, and watch the world go by.
author: Michael H.

description:
1.  It's way to pricey!  I ordered a bagel with cream cheese and ham and orange juice.  Total price: $12.00   That's astronomically high!

2.  Great internet BUT you are only limited to 2 hours and then it cuts you off.  I always thought that a cafe should always offer free unlimited internet access.

3.  Food is good but I've had better.

I give it a 2.  Lower your prices and offer longer time limits on the internet and I just MAY go back.
author: Santiago M.

description:
This is my favorite coffee shop in San Francisco!  The coffee is more expensive than most places but that's because its organic & free trade. 

If you like soy milk, I suggest ordering a medium soy mocha.  Delicious!  

The employees are so nice too.  They go above and beyond most places to treat the regulars well.

One negative, when there is a line, it can take a little while to get in and out.  But Quetzal coffee drinks make it more than worth the wait.
author: Freaky P.

description: Latte was good and baked goods were too. House coffee was very weak and needed a shot of espresso to wake it up. Atmosphere was okay but crowded bulky tables made it feel cafe-like. Nice unique offering make this a 3 star for me--good selection of baked goods, iMacs available for free (about 12 of them set up in a separate area), nice unique music, although it was a tad too loud for my liking. Staff was not overly friendly or on the ball.
author: Juanita C.

description:
Great beverages, food and atmosphere. Good internet connection (with purchase). New extended evening hours that make it a great place to hang out late!

I LOVE this place!
author: Briana F.

description: I f'ing love this place now.  They just changed their hours, open until 2:30am... and they have beer.  I usually have tea here after eating dinner.  Now I finally have a good noisy place to concentrate when I have a lot of work to catch up on.  Honestly, I haven't tried the coffee yet but I'm sure it's fine.  Their beans are fair trade and I try and support socially conscious businesses so its a win win all around.
author: Nathan V.

description:
Quetzal's location on Polk street, between Bush and Sutter, works out great for me since I live within a few blocks, The Cafe takes up a sizable portion of the block, which allows for a respectable amount of outdoor seating. The interior has depth, delineated by ramps and the segmented  public computer section, and plenty of seating as you make your way from the front counter to the back of the Cafe. Quetzal also benefits from an abundance of daylight, which is a plus since I prefer natural lighting whenever possible. At night, the interior lighting allows for reading or studying and is not overly luminous for those who enjoy subtlety.

Although I haven't deviated from the standard coffee and tea drinks, Quetzal has a wide selection of pastries, some of which are vegan, and sandwiches. The service I've experienced at Quetzal has always been friendly with a keen sense for efficiency. I once paid for a coffee and received exact change for my $5 bill before I even handed the cashier the money.

For being located on a bustling street, Quetzal is a great place to stop by if you're looking to find a place to study, enjoy some organic fair-trade coffee, or access the Internets.
author: Chris P.

description:
better than Starbucks, better than Peet's, before than your local coffee houses...with it's fantastic staff, delicious coffe drinks, yummy shakes and fantastic food - Quetzal is my favorite place to meet friends, have lunch or catch up reading my newspaper.

Wish there would be more locations. 2 thumbs up! Keep up the good work.
author: Kimberly T.

description: Awesome cafe. Excellent friendly service, great tasting coffee and cool atmosphere. The place to be on polk street
author: Kalen F.

description:
Quetzal is one of my favorite places.  The coffee is excellent.  And I've lived off their Meaty Fritata's (My spelling is probably off on that one, but the food is  worth walking in the rain for. )

I've never had a coffee shop, before now, that offered to hold a croissant just for me for my Sunday fix.
author: Nikki P.

description: The lounge was a bit cramped. But there are plenty of power outlets. Purchase required for Wifi access code.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Quetzal is one of my favorite cafes in the city. The staff make a mean latte and the food is always fresh, delicious, and with big portions. They offer a huge range of awesome vegan baked goods that would impress even the most staunch butter-lovers. 

I think my favorite part of this place is how warm it feels inside. Polk street doesn't usually feel "homey" but this cafe does. 

The only downside of the place is that sometimes the staff play mariachi music for hours on end. Not the most relaxing choice of tunes...
author: Laura K.

description: New to the city...and without internet, Quetzal is open late (2:30am on Sat) with decent wifi and workspace included with a latte. What more do you need? :)
author: Raul R.

description: Our experience was limited (a drip coffee to go), but we could tell this was THE coffee shop in the area. It had a great atmosphere, a friendly staff, and a ton of beverage options. You could tell that a lot of the people who were plopped down and surfing the web were regulars. If we ever stay in this part of town again, we'll definitely be back.
author: Chris G.

description: Apparently, internet cafe coffee shops in the middle of the day are the new singles bars for the un- and underemployed.  Who knew?  Needless to say, I was quite pleased to discover this, and the house chardonnay is not too bad.
author: Mason G.

description:
I have been going to Quetzal for the past month, because I am prepping for major exam. This place seemed like a good fit with many outlets, a lot of available tables,  and unlimited internet with a purchase.
Lately I noticed service in this place has been worsening every time I visit this place. 

Staff is just not nice to you, Internet is now limited to 2 hours per purchase, (basically buy more, or get out of here policy) the food is still ok but definently overpriced.

For a person like me, who needs to spend about 5 hours in this place at a time, the new Internet policy is a major drawback, I don't mind paying for food and drinks when I'm there, but I don't want to be forced to do it every 2 hours.
author: Alex R.

description: This is my fav place to study. They have awesome soup, sandwiches, and friendly staff!
author: Kissy F.

description: Great place, good food. They just need to learn how to make a decent mimosa. I got (and watched one being made). It's predominately orange juice.
author: Nicole C.

description:
some interesting menu items and solid coffee products.  i cannot give them a preferable rating because the use of internet is convoluted and asinine.  you have to be able to provide them with your MAC address and then they go into the back and register this MAC address with their router.  then you have to reboot.  this is a stupid process and can be more efficient.  this is a HUGE pain in the ass when there are customers waiting for service because the same person who is running the register has to do this for you and if you run into any problems you are looking at 20-30 minutes just to get online.  after you have paid for it.  

it's ok if you are just going for a bite and some coffee but don't expect to get online or be productive here.
author: W G.

description: I have been coming to Quetzal for twelve years & it never gets old.  Yes, they have amazing vegan pies, cookies, etc and their espresso is delicious, but what really keeps me coming back is Wayne & his wonderful crew.   They know their regulars by name and remember our orders before we say them.  Not only is the service amazing, but the internet access with ample seating and electrical plugs is a plus.  I could sit here for hours with my laptop (& I do).  Quetzal provides a comfortable, friendly space whether I want to focus for hours on work, or hang with friends.  Oh, & the Happy Hour is nice:)
author: Deb Doran D.

description: Sometimes this place feels more like a library than a cafe.  Most of the people are quietly reading or studying or doing whatever it is they're doing on their laptops.  It's a great coffee shop though.  The drinks are good, service is polite, and it never gets too crowded.  I usually come here when I need to study and I usually get a lot done.
author: Dinesh M.

description:
Quetzal Internet Cafe has a pretty nice setup but there are a few things that if changed would make this a 5 star joint in my book. It is sometimes kind of loud in here. It's not that there is the mumblings of a lot of people but that you can really hear other people's conversations from across the room. One group of people speaking at normal conversation level seems to echo. They might invest in sound absorbers, which if correctly hung from the ceilings and critical corners, would absorb much of the ambient noise. 
The second thing is it's a bit awkward having to order, receive and prepare your coffee right at the register. I get conscious of the people behind me waiting and feel pressure to quickly get on with it. 
Otherwise, I think this place is great and I'll probably keep coming back when I'm in this neighborhood to work for a few hours on my laptop. 
The coffee is good! Food is pretty good. Sandwiches might be overpriced but the pizza isn't a bad value.
Right-o
author: jason h.

description: My close friend went to Quetzal to use their computers and ordered a bagel w/ salmon and cream cheese. The salmon had this oily glaze over it and looked funny but she ate it anyway cause she was starving. That night she started to get sick and vomit. The next day she was really sick and went to the emergency room at the hospital. NEVER EVER order food from this place. Beware!
author: Brian C.

description: I had no idea this place existed! We were just looking for a quick post gym bite and at first I thought this was strictly a coffee and pastries place but boy does this place have an extended menu. They even have something called a Turkish breakfast which I was intrigued by! Got the homemade cashew granola with non fat yogurt which was tasty and fiancee got the bagel. Service was quick and prices reasonable. Definitely a good experience!
author: Cathy T.

description: I have been coming to this place since I moved to the city. Totally cool people, made friends with a couple of the guys that work there right off. They are huge and the ceilings are really high, Very nice environment to work in. I have sat in there all day drinking coffee, eating great food, and working on the Internet. Try them out.
author: Michael L.

description: The coffee is very good, good breakfast and lunch selection, the guys that work there are GREAT and so nice and friendly, Thanks Quetzal for wake me up every morning.......mmmm also every afternoon zzzzz....just one suggestion when you guys will have Colombian Coffee?
author: Carlos E.

description:
i really like quetzal.

i have only actually eaten here once properly -- i had a gigantic amazing sandwich on fresh ciabatta with crisp greens and zingy sauce.  as a frequenter of this place, i have seen a lot of the food come out to other people which makes me really excited about trying their pizza and some of their breakfast sandwiches (this one guy got this amazing thing that looked like a mix of eggs benedict and an open-faced sandwich)!

i come here often for coffee, hot chocolate and relaxing.  every time, everyone has been exceedingly helpful.  they also have a frequent buyer club which saves you 10% if you are a loyal customer. :)

free wifi.  macs with internet access. 
food is a tad pricey for me, but it's definitely tasty.
nice ambiance, plenty of seating, lots of outlets.
solid 4 stars.
author: Lily B.

description: Cool little place. Went there for a quick snack and was very intrigued by the selection of munch-ables and delights. They had food fit for everyone from the picky (like me) to the vegan. Grabbed myself an apple cinnamon muffin and a chai latte. YUM! Will definitely check it out again.
author: Jessica L.

description: There employees have 8 hour day plus no lunches or breaks. That's an outrage! Not to mention illegal. I'd have to see a major change in that department before I put a dime of my money in their register.
author: chad l.

description: This place is great! Stumbled in here after trying to go to Leland (they are remodeling, open again tomorrow I think). Anyway, Quetzal is laid back, plenty of room, places for plugging in computers, free wifi, a discount club for regulars and good, prompt service. I've just had the drinks but the sandwiches look really delicious.
author: Rachel M.

description: Lovely coffee and nice atmosphere. Good to work here I imagine if you are looking for internet cafes.
author: james j.

description: This is a cool 'net cafe on Polk--friendly staff, excellent organic/fair trade coffee, and plenty of seating.  They offer a decent food menu, as well.  It's never too busy inside, so it's just the perfect atmosphere to get your work done, read a book, or have a chat over a cup of joe.
author: Marsha Z.

description: Organic, fair-trade, and delicious vegetarian options are all over their menu. Great location and lots of space inside to sit back, chat, or get some extra work done online. Their internet connection is nice and strong throughout the whole location - my first choice for logging on away from home.
author: Victoria K.

description: This place is good for coffee. This place is good for free internet with your own laptop. This place costs like 10 cents per minute if you use there computers. The pastries are pretty good as well. My friends who are internet cafe users don't like that they have a password that changes daily. I guess they feel guilty for getting the password and not buying something. Some how I always going to this place on those days that there are festivals and I've been day drinking...Thanks Quetzal!
author: Stafford J.

description: I came here when I first got to SF 6 months ago, and still haven't found a cup of cafe mocha any better than the one I had here.
author: Deanna C.

description:
I used to study here with my ex... A few things that come to mind: the tables were semi-wobbly, the seats seemed lower than the tables, and the Internet was super spotty... The most annoying thing: little flies that would buzz around our coffee and water. 

Seems a bit fishy, no? Nowadays, I only come here if I'm desperate for somewhere to study.
author: Travel Swagger R.

description:
This is one of my favorites.  I used to haunt this place frequently when I lived over in Russian Hill/ Nob Hill.  The coffee is great with nice sizes.  I'm particularly fond that they actually give you real, solid mugs for your Joe.  I hate it when those cookie-cutter places only give you paper cups whether you're staying or going...but I digress.
The ambiance is roomy and airy with outside and inside seating available and plenty of interesting foot traffic.  A decent WiFi awaits among the plants in this industrial meets Andean-colored decor.  With plenty of wireless for all (there are even some switches to plug into for the net 1.0  types that are still among us- so options are aplenty!!) and plenty of plugs, so you won't be left hangin' when the music stops.
The food is very good whether you're in the mood for a tasty sandwich  (love the Quetzal club and Randy-baby),  a hefty smoothie that packs a punch with all the health-club trimmings, or just something sweet.  
I also like the frequent buyer club they offer.  Anyway, enough reading of this review - go and put it to your own caffeine-cravin' palette!
author: Adam F.

description: Fair trade organic coffee that still tastes delicious?  I'm for it.  Granted, I'm no coffee connoisseur, but Quetzal has not disappointed.  They have a wide variety of coffee drinks and smoothies and a large tea selection.  I haven't had many meals there, but the pastries are delicious (I recommend the lemon poppyseed muffin smothered in frosting).  The ambiance is not incredible, but since it's an internet cafe I tend to have a fleeting feeling of being in another country every time I walk in, and I like that.  Oh, and I've joined the frequent buyer program.  I have no idea how it works, but every once in awhile I get a coupon!
author: Christina D.

description: I was here on Friday, 8/18/06 to meet my date. The white chocolate mocha with thick whip cream is the best. So far, their coffee has a strong chocolate taste. Boy, I thought Starbucks and Peets are on top of my list. Quetzal, you guys really rocks with white chocolate mocha. Keep up the good work, I will come back more and more.
author: Linh D.

description:
If you need a place to study, this is a very good option. Lots of good-sized tables, sufficiently spaced apart, offer enough privacy and quiet to get some work done. In fact, when I went there, most of the tables had only one occupant and a laptop. If you don't want to bring your laptop, there are nice apple computers - lots and lots of them - that you can rent. 

I got iced macchiato and a cookie - didn't like them. The drink was too sweet, and the cookie was a joke and tasted old. So 3 stars for giving a good study place, but no star for the food. (There's a huge menu though, so I might just have tried the wrong choices on the menu.)
author: Ryan M.

description: It is just the perfect distance away from Alliance Francaise and they are super quick so I can grab my mocha and GIGANTOR sized croissant (quite tasty, FYI) and run back to the courtyard to laze in the sun during my mid-morning lesson break.  I do love the cafe at La Cave, but admittedly, I need to get up  and stretch my legs after sitting through the first part of my lesson.
author: Hiromi N.

description: This place is okay. I don't care for the breakfast here. It's under seasoned, and the eggs don't taste like eggs. The price is a bit high as well. The desserts are better, but not the best. Although, I do like the drinks they serve here. I haven't tried the lunch here yet.  The staff is friendly, and this place is convenient for a hang out spot with their free wifi. Dog friendly since they have outdoor seating :)
author: Mina P.

description:
The new guy with  the dark hair has an attitude up the a**.  perhaps he is not comfortable yet with his gayness???  Who knows but if I see him at the counter I won't go in.



The years are showing in this place, could be a bit cleaner, it is always COLD in here and the glare from the sunlight makes it difficult sometimes to see my laptop screen.

Lots of scetchy Polk street types here with the occassional lost tourist.

One time this 2o something chick sat next to me and took out her cell phone and proceeded to yack away very loudly like she was the only person in the cafe.  I asked her to please take it somewhere else or outside and she went into a frenzy.  This is the type of customer you will run into often here so beware of that.

Lastly why they keep the bathroom locked I will never understand.  If you want to go you have to ask one of the employees behind the counter to buzz you in.  So if there is a line and they are busy you have to wait.
author: t c.

description: One of my favoriate coffee shops in the city tucked away behind trees and whose sign is unfortunately obscured.  I love the Indonesian/Southeast Asian decor and merchandise, the mellow clientele, and the cool dark ambiance. They have free wireless and Macs for you to use while you gaze outside onto Polk street pedestrians. I'm a fan of the smoothies... albiet they are extremely overpriced.  The all organic coffee I have yet to discover.  I recommend this place for those art students looking to sketch at the corner coffee shop or anti-starbucks coffee drinkers looking to hang out.
author: Jenny C.

description: Superb internet coffee shop. Spacious, strong coffee, enough outlets to satisfy even the most hard-core peripheral junk. Music is not too loud or obtrusive, super-friendly staff, great food (loved their selection of power breakfast), and clean. In short, your ideal office-for-one-day.
author: Steven D.

description:
the cafe itself doesn't suck, but the layout and the ambiance don't give me a cozy, welcoming feeling. it feels cramped, but not in a cute, French way. it just has bad Feng Shui. come to think of it, i actually like the entrance the best. (3)

their food selection seems to be pretty good. (4)

the WiFi is free, but unfortunately the speed was abysmal the day i was there: 691/302 (1)

one of the better points is that they made an effort to put power everywhere. you'll find power strips below the benches - a very nice touch. also, i've always gotten great service there from the staff. (+1)

so, as part of my search to find a great cafe in which to work, i give Quetzal a 3 star rating.
author: FrOg SoU P.

description: Great place for caffeine and non caffeine beverages. Friendly staff and free WiFi makes this place one of my favorite neighborhood cafes. Glad to know too the they support fair trade business practice.
author: Pres L.

description: I'm lost on the name, but the place is chill.  Large space with plenty of room to sit and work.  Coffee is really good, and food is decent.   Free wifi makes my work happen.   Dig it.
author: Dan G.

description: Love the tuna and capers samich here...It's what I usually get. The place is usually busy into the evening hours with patrons on their lap tops. Staff is friendly and the service is quick.
author: Teddy d.

description: I really like this cafe here.  Very different vibe to it than your average Starbucks.  Don't get me wrong, Starbucks is great for your everyday grab and go, but this cafe offers a little more ambience for say, a nice lazy afternoon chat over some good food too.  their sandwiches are a bit pricey but really good.  they have these really sinfully good chocolate/mocha shakes that they whip up too.  Very big selection of coffees and teas with daily specials posted.  Service is a bit lacking but doesn't really matter to me. im just there to drink my coffee and use the internet.  id recommend this place for an after dinner coffee place.  it's kinda in a sketchy location but s'all good.
author: Peggy W.

description: I L-O-V-E this cafe! The staff is friendly and courteous...the atmosphere is fantastic. I am happy that my apartment is nearby. Best matte latte ever! When I'm feeling blue Quetzal provides that pick-me-up that I require.
author: Sherie R.

description: This is a great place to drink coffee & surf the internet.  I have never had problems using my wireless laptop there but my friend has gone a couple times and the internet has been down.  I like their smoothies & pastries but sometimes the service is a little off.
author: Mahogany G.

description: All I needed for internet access to my laptop was one of those cord thingies- and it was free.  They are generous with their servings, but I'd rather go across the street for food than pay their high prices.  The art is interesting- and so is the artist- who spends most of his days in the coffee shop.  Don't plan on getting any studying done if you happen to meet him.
author: CAKE E.

description: It's been said but let me reiterate: free wifi, outlets galore, space, caffeine, and nice staff. Also, close to the Wholefoods with my favorite salad bar. I think I might stay here until I finish my dissertation.
author: Jen M.

description: Love this place! It's a regular place I patron, usually after going to the gym. Their lox and bagel plate is fresh and filling, and their orange juice and coffee hits the spot. The fish has not been fresh once in I'd say two years, but that still keeps me bringing myself and friends back for more. It's the perfect spot for coffee and chatting, or just being along reading a book or magazine. The waffles with fresh fruit are quite good too.
author: David G.

description: Good bites and coffee -- although the prices are starting to get a little steep for what you get. Simple breakfast food. Health conscious?...Order the 8 egg whites scramble breakfast. One of the few clean and cozy coffee places on Polk. The staff is friendly, cheerful, and can't be blamed for the prices.
author: Dan E.

description:
We were walking around looking for breakfast when the "Organic Coffee" sign in the window lured us in. I was sold upon seeing the breakfast pizza on the menu - scrambled eggs with dill sauce, topped with lox. It was massive - I only managed to eat half of it, even though it was delicious. 

The frittata was just okay, but smothered in a pretty good guacamole, so it'll be pardoned.

I'm still coming back the next time I'm in SF. Their Shakes menu looked divine.
author: Ngoc H.

description: Their internet won't let you connect to Meebo.com.  They won't let you stream KQED too, sigh.  How does a free-trade coffee house justify restricting their companies internet?
author: Rachel B.

description: I have been to Quetzal possibly 50 times and have nothing but good to say.  It is located very conveniently on Polk street and has lots of outdoor tables which are very popular.  The location layout is long, narrow and sits on a low hill.  The interior has three levels that start with the cafe/ordering station, a little higher is the Mac stations and the final area is sitting area for laptop users and others.  The coffee is great and the staff are very friendly and always quick to help.  I have had many of their pies, etc. and they are always great.  Many of the inside guests are wi-fi users and the place is always busy.  It does quite well as a casual cafe and I see many people eat entrees compared to coffee places.  I recommend it fully.
author: Cush D.

description: Very good coffee drinks!!! They roast it there. Location is not good for tourists - locals only dude. There is wifi, but with charge.
author: ji k.

description: I love the coffee here, too bad the service is wishy washy...I guess I have been spoiled by starbucks great service. I also filled out info to get a special # and never received it...I guess they threw my info in the garbage.
author: Dee D.

description: Great coffee, great atmosphere and run by some cool people! We spend Sunday after workout hanging out here. The staff is very attentive and friendly, and everything on the menu has been great.
author: Jen H.

description: Its quetzal time on saturdays at 3PM - thats when all the french students at alliance have their break...including me ;) I know their coffee is good and strong...but their hot chocolate is incredible. Some whipped cream on top and I am riding the sugar high for the second part of my class.... Their smoothies are very good too and the cakes and cookies, macaroons, muffins and bagels are always fresh and tasty!! The staff is friendly and remembers your order from a week agao...Awesome
author: Conny F.

description: I manage an apartment building just 1/2 block from Quetzal. I love  stopping in for a great cup of coffee and my favorite healthy, high protein breakfast--their Power Fritatta. An all-egg whites baked fluffy treat with tomatoes, cheese, and spinach. Amazing. This place has a neighborly and unpretentious offering of fair trade organic coffee, calm yet fun atmosphere, friendly staff, killer foccocia, garden-fresh salads, and they even have vegan desserts along side other yummy sweet treats. Go for the food and hang out for the atmosphere.
author: Sutter House A.

description: J says:  I take classes at the alliance francaise around the corner and this is the perfect place to stop by for a coffee break or for lunch.  You can sit all day and work there and no one will come bother you.  Service is friendly and pretty quick.  The salads come in large portions but are on the pricey side (cobb salad $12).  The lattes are ok, same price as starbucks.
author: Jen Ken H.

description: Oh, this is so much more than an internet cafe.  The coffee is roasted on site, the salads and sandwiches are to "live for."  Soak in the international flavor of the crowd and consider the central american arts and crafts while sipping a Morrocan mint tea, or a perfect macchiato.
author: Jeffrey T.

description: Pricey, but they have CLOTH napkins: And portions are the size of your head. Good food, good smoothies...I had a warm, sunlit table by the window in which to bask and enjoy my meal, in the midst of a hectic workday.
author: Jo S.

description: I like this place, it has a nice product mix. They've got a little bit of everything, all the basics of a cafe plus computers,retail, beer, gallery space, and potential for some really awesome movie nights (screen projector).  I enjoy having choices, and this place definitely has something for everyone in the group. It's a nice study/hangout/chill spot. free wi-fi. $4 beers on tap. The owner was working when I went in last friday night, really nice guy, he's the older fella. Chat him up if you see him!
author: AA B.

description: I really like this place, good coffee, I want to try them all. Also the people who work there are pretty nice.
author: Aidan G.

description: Best coffee in the city.  Nice atmosphere, but seats aren't too comfy, and the location isn't superb.  Food is good, but a bit pricey for the overall laid back scene.
author: Brent H.

description: It's a nice place to go any time of day.  They have a good tea selection, and their coffee is really good too.  If you have a sweet tooth, defnitely go for the toffee coffee cake.  It's mm mm good.  Make sure ya get it heated because it tastes even better warm.
author: Miss T.

description: This is a great place to see all the eclectic people of San Francisco. Its in my hood and I love to sit outside and be entertained by all the varietals of humanity that wander about Polk Street.  The coffee and food is always fresh and the staff are always friendly. This is a great place to chill.  I only wish they left there outdoor seating available late into the evening.
author: Carlos C.

description: Quetzal is a good spot if you have a lot of work to do, want coffee, and need a place to spread out your papers, books, and computer. The atmosphere is mellow enough to get work done, the tables are good sized, and there are plenty of outlets to plug in your computer.  The coffee's decent and the salads are good, but avoid the pizzas (think soggy crust, sauce and toppings with no taste, and some kind of not-so-great cheese slopped on there). I guess cafes aren't the best place to order pizza though.  The cakes aren't so great either (they taste like they came from costco or something). Oh, and minus one star for the not so friendly service (is it that hard to say hello and smile??) and the fact that you have to walk up to the front to ask them to buzz you into the bathroom in the back everytime you have to go...
author: SL N.

description: This place serves up original drinks and warm food, but it's so dark!  I come here for the wifi but to compensate for their floor to ceiling windows facing the sun, they have the shades down for the most part which is tires your eyes if you have to be on a laptop for more than an hour.
author: Samantha W.

description: Hip, cool and great food. Eclectic ambiance with decent service. Gotta love the fact that you can pop in, get an awesome REAL latte and use the internet at the crossroads of town.
author: Paul F.

description:
This place is so much better than Starbucks or Peet's that you won't go back to them once you try it.  The coffee has a much deeper flavor and a real mule kick.  I get a mix of decaf--delicious and full full bodied--and regular (a boatload of caffeine)  If I drank straight regular, I'd take one sip, fly out the door and slam into the shopping cart of one of the Polk Street homeless.   If I drank their espresso, I'd be permanently on their ceiling.  All this for $1.45 or, if you want a day's worth of java, $1.65.

Nice scene in Quetzal's and outside--at the tables on the street it's mainly aging Queens, and inside it's hip people at computers.  And gorgeous hemp South American sweaters hanging on the walls.

The toilets are very clean but you have to get the counter guy to buzz you in.  BTW the counter guys are helpful but not chatty--they are usually too busy serving the line of Polk Street types waiting for  their coffees.

So, give this place a try.  If you're a regular, they take the last four numbers of your phone number and after ten cups--not all on the same day, I hope--you get a freebie.  Believe me, after ten cups, you have earned that freebie.   This coffee is so strong that it keeps your eyes permanently open.   And it's so much better than Red Bull and those poisonous drinks that rot your intestines and eat your stomach lining.  Who drinks that swill??????

P.S. Notice that I haven't mentioned the Fair Trade aspect of Quetzal's.  That's between you and your political conscience.  I don't drink their coffee because I want to save the world, I just like the taste, flavor, and price.
author: Murray S.

description: Nice place to people watch while you're having coffee outside, but I have had better brewed coffee.  Staff were somewhat surly....
author: Norman B.

description: I really like Quetzal because of their studious atmosphere and the Carmel Macchiatos ( the best  in Sf so far, but I just moved here so I am not sure how much that counts :P). It's a little chilly inside at times (but then again I am often cold), and the restrooms are not the best, however, it's a great place to get your work/study done. I would not recommend using their internet computers because they are slow and expensive, but they do provide free wifi. You have to ask the staff for a password, which changes daily.  The food is quite good but pricey for a coffee shop. Overall, a great place to get your work done!
author: Natalia P.

description: My first review, ever, so here goes. I was in Quetzal towards the end of last February & I got on one of their I-Macs. I was on for a couple of hours, then paid for my time. The total seemed a little high so I mentioned this to the cashier. He said that I was on the computer for 2 hrs & 40 minutes. I knew for a fact that I was logged on from 8:12 to 10:12 exactly. Making it 2 hrs. even. I told him this, & he said that there was nothing he could do. I then went to the manager & told him the situation. He looked into their computer records & decided that even though the cashier had made a mistake, he was going to give me "the benefit of the doubt" & refund a mere $5, even though at 16 cents a minute a 40 minute discrepency would amount to $6.40. This all may not seem like much, but the experience really soured me on the whole place. I was talked down to & treated as if I was trying to cheat the system. They have good food & a great ambiance, but keep track of your minutes if you use their desktops.
author: Richard C.

description: One of my favorite coffee shops for getting some work done--solid lattes, lots of choices for food, and friendly service. I've never had trouble finding a table, the wifi is reliable, and outlets are abundant.
author: Katherine N.

description: am i the only person who thinks this place is expensive?  its $10 for a smallish sandwich and a tiny salad.  i was stil hungry so i went back and got a vegan oatmeal chocolate chip cookie.  mmm.  $2.74.  one cookie.
author: pete c.

description: this place is awesome. love the smoked salmon platter. great beer and wine selection. always a place to sit inside and out and theres a public parklet on the other side of the sidewalk if all the outside tables are taken up.  hard to stray to any other of polk streets awesome cafe when this place has got so much to offer
author: Liz R.

description: This is my go to place when I need to focus on my school work, in a relaxed, quiet environment, and perhaps grab a beverage. The staff is very warm and welcoming. I think that their smoothies are a little pricey and aren't the tastiest but they have plenty of other options. I will be back to Quetzal tonight to study for my finals. To get the key for the wireless network you must make a purchase.
author: kevin g.

description: Good spot for a first date.  Spacious, well-decorated, wi-fi.  Wasn't too crowded in late afternoon on a weekday.  Friendly/flirty staff.  Yummy-looking baked goods, I'll have to go back for some of those.  Cocoa was delicious.  And environmentally and socially concerned, yay!
author: D G.

description: Great service and dependability.  A place I wouldn't mind going to everyday.
author: Violet B.

description:
i am at quetzal every single day. yes- they know me and ask if i'm ordering the usual when i walk in the door- which is an aspect i could take or leave. sometimes coffee shop employees are WAY too friendly and i am a big fan of feeling anonymous, but they're good people in there, so i'm tolerant.
some times we grab coffee to go and sometimes we sit at the tables out front- i usually prefer the former. one cannot sit outside without being constantly harassed by the neighborhood ya-hoos for cigarettes or a light or change- it's infuriating. 
the coffee is damn good. great even. it's organic and exquisitely made. perfect temperatures, foam quality, and espresso pulls. it is without question the highlight and only reason to go.
i guess i dig the pastries- they're humongous. i don't know if i've ever finished a muffin or a scone. and they're not sticky skanky sweet like at corporate places. 
all in all-
great coffee. not a place to kick it.
author: gertie s.

description: When you need a place to sit and work all day, this is it.  You may have to go to the counter to order but no one will bother you for hanging out for hours.  Food is fresh stuff - healthy but also tasty and appealing.  For those like me who don't drink coffee, a real find - an extensive TEA menu!  I also like the imported handi-craft goods for sale - fun to look at even if you don't buy.
author: Lynne H.

description: Yes, this place is big so it is not difficult to find a place to sit. The downside though is that it's maybe too big because it did remind me of a library. The menu is good and so was the coffee. The place is comfortable but lacks some warmth
author: sonali p.

description: great place to study, if you like the cafe feeling. the hot sandwich's rock my sandwich world. they are delicious, and all come with a small mixed green salad with raspberry vinaigrette dressing. mmm you gotta go here!
author: Ashley M.

description: this place is always bright, clean, and half empty (i mean half full).  i feel good drinking the fair trade coffee there.  i love how this is in the part of town that's FAR FAR FAR away from the tourists.  it's not easily accessible for others except if you live in the hood.  AWESOME.   (i am just being nasty.  the 1, 3, and 19 drop you off right at the corner).
author: Arthemis G.

description: they have free wifi and plenty of routers to plug into.  they have breakfast and protein shakes.  which makes it a perfect place for me to get work done.
author: Alan N.

description: good food, lot of choices!  The veggie cheddar melt was awesome. A bit pricey and over-crowded, however definitely worth it. Free wifi is always a plus.
author: Beena A.

description: went there today after looking at some scary apartments for rent in the tendernob. it was nice to climb out of graffiti-land and suddenly find ourselves at such a cute clean cafe. i had an apricot scone. it was surprisingly dense and tasty without being loud in a buttery or sugary way. shanghai smoothie had a really nice fresh strawberry taste, but the texture was a little weird, almost slimy. coffee unremarkable. and it was kind of annoying trying to find a table-- the place wasn't busy but almost every empty table was covered in dirty plates and mugs, and the dirty dishware was still sitting out when we left half an hour later.
author: Dana D.

description: I could not believe that after YEARS of being a loyal customer I went in to the cafe last nite to ask for a small coffee and if it could please be put in a large coffee mug. I was told that can not do that, and they charge by the cup! I get this if the cup is paper and is counted in inventory, however it was for there, so it would of just been a coffee mug. Also I was kicked out of the WiFi WHICH is not longer FREE, 2 times in less than an hour. The staff is no longer happy and fun, but under the thumb of a greedy money driven partner that has destroyed the atmosphere there. The place is no longer clean, especially at nite! or the partner is doing sometype of work inside the cafe, painting tables, or some other lighting, or something, it just no longer is a calm relaxing place to enjoy one another get work or homework done, which I find so sad, another place destroyed by greed, and LACK of customer service at its finest. Also the quality of the food has really dropped, that is if they remember to place the order, or if you can get anyone to help you after 9pm, usually the staff is cut by that time, leaving you wonder if they are even open, because no one is at the counter. I'm so sad to see a great place go to shit, that's the reason there is no more Memphis Quetzal. Lucky us got that partner, dude this is not Memphis it's San Francisco - we support our locals with respect, as they should treat us, Starbucks is looking great and tasting better every day I don't return to your establishment.
author: liza m.

description: Great coffee, friendly and efficient service. Could be a better lay out for sitting in. Tables are very close together. I usually get mine to go though so am pretty happy!
author: Paul R.
